Ms. Eason’s engaging, superbly acted drama takes place in a Chicago rock club that’s been in business for a quarter-century and looks like it hasn’t been given a good scrub since it opened its doors.

headline: Our Cosmic Selves

lead_paragraph: JONI MITCHELL beat Carl Sagan to the punch. She sang “we are stardust, billion-year-old carbon” in her 1970 song “Woodstock.” That was three years before Mr. Sagan wrote about humans’ being made of “star-stuff” in his book “The Cosmic Connection” — a point he would later convey to a far larger audience in his 1980 television series, “Cosmos.”

headline: Learning Through Tinkering
abstract: If we want children to be independent thinkers, we should give them the tools — and the challenges — to figure stuff out for themselves.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — My 9-year-old daughter is in the midst of a “pioneer” unit in her third grade class. It’s a great example of a project-based curriculum: The kids are developing math skills by determining what and how much they can pack without overloading wagons for a cross-country trek. They roll a “twist of fate” die that presents (virtual) obstacles they might have faced in the late 19th century — bad weather, loss of livestock, etc. — and then have to problem-solve to get their trek back on track. They’re reading a variety of historical perspectives, such as Louise Erdrich’s “The Birchbark House” and Laura Ingalls Wilder’s “Little House” books. And perhaps most important, they’re learning about self-sufficiency and resilience — and how even the youngest kids needed it in spades.

headline: No Springtime Renewal in the Job Market
keywords: ['Labor and Jobs', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Unemployment', 'United States Economy', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: Are March’s dismal jobs numbers a fluke, or the start of something bad?
lead_paragraph: It will take another few months to see if the unexpectedly dismal job market in March was a fluke or the start of something bad. Economists had expected the latest employment report, released on Friday, to show 250,000 newly-created jobs last month, in line with the encouraging monthly tallies in the past year. But the economy added only 126,000 jobs and totals for January and February were revised down by 69,000 jobs.

headline: How Jesse Malin, a Musician and Restaurateur, Spends His Sundays
abstract: Not all New York notables begin their Sundays at 7 or 8 a.m. Jesse Malin, for one, prefers a gentler start.
lead_paragraph: Not all New York notables begin their Sundays at 7 or 8 a.m. Jesse Malin, for one, prefers a gentler start. “It depends on how many sodas I had the night before, but I usually get up around noon,” said Mr. Malin, 47, a musician and partner in several restaurants and bars in the East Village. “Used to be a little later.” Mr. Malin, a native of Queens, started hitting the East Village as a 12-year-old punk rocker and never lost his crush on the neighborhood, which is still digging out from the building explosion and seven-alarm fire on March 26. He currently lives alone on Avenue A. His new album, “New York Before the War,” ruminates on life today in the borough he calls the Old Apple. “You walk out your door and a song can unfold, a story, a life,” he said.

headline: Parents and Teachers Meet in a New York Minute (or 5 if They’re Lucky)
abstract: In middle and high school, most of the city’s public school teachers have at least 150 students; the few hours set aside for formal conferences can be an exercise in chaos.
lead_paragraph: On parent-teacher conference day at Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan last week, scores of tense parents bunched together in the lobby, penned in behind yellow caution tape. At exactly 1 p.m., the tape dropped and the grown-ups stampeded up the stairs, jostling to get to the front of the pack.

headline: Why the Trans-Pacific Partnership Matters
keywords: ['Trans-Pacific Partnership', 'International Trade and World Market', 'United States International Relations', 'Income Inequality', 'Currency', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: If the Trans-Pacific Partnership fails, the national security of America will be severely harmed.
lead_paragraph: AFTER five years, American-led negotiations over the Trans-Pacific Partnership, a trade liberalization agreement with 11 other countries that collectively account for 40 percent of the world’s economy, are nearly complete. The next step is for Congress to allow for the same legislative process — an up-or-down vote on the deal — that it applied to recent trade pacts, including the North American Free Trade Agreement of 1993 and the United States-South Korea free trade agreement of 2011.

headline: The Look North Inuit Art Gallery in Red Hook for Arctic Sculpture
abstract: The Look North Inuit Art Gallery is devoted to contemporary sculpture by Alaska’s indigenous people and other Arctic artists.
lead_paragraph: There is a surprising and fluid connection between the indigenous art of the Alaskan Inuit and Red Hook, Brooklyn, and it is Jim Clark. Mr. Clark, a longtime fisherman and first mate on vessels that regularly ply the Bering Sea, also happens to be an art collector. After a dozen years of gathering contemporary native sculptures, he started his art gallery, LOOK NORTH, in 2007. No bland cubed cheese was served at the opening; 25 pounds of king crab vanished almost as fast as an eel in the sand.

headline: Review: Haydn’s ‘Seven Last Words of Christ,’ by 2 String Quartets
abstract: The string quartet version of the work came around twice this week, performed by the Dodd String Quartet and by the Attacca Quartet.
lead_paragraph: We tend to think of Joseph Haydn as a consolidator: the composer who drew together numerous musical currents to perfect the symphony and the string quartet, defining forms of the Classical and Romantic eras. But Haydn was also an innovator, with what James Webster, in The New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians, calls “a ‘modernist’ tendency to problematize music rather than merely to compose it.”

headline: Review: A Writhing, Emotional Revival of Wagner’s ‘Tannhäuser’
abstract: The baritone Christian Gerhaher made a rare appearance in a revival of Wagner’s opera at the Staatsoper in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The straight-arrow, even prissy Wolfram delivers the first entry in the song contest at the heart of Wagner’s “Tannhäuser.” In the choreographer Sasha Waltz’s spare, elegant staging of the opera here, men fall to the ground as he sings, so overcome are they by his stirring performance.

headline: The Shabab’s Horrifying Resurgence
abstract: The terrorists seemed to be on the run in Somalia. But now in Kenya, they are back with a deadly sectarian vengeance.
lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — Kenya is reeling from the shock of the massacre, early on Thursday, of 147 people in an attack by Somali militants on a college. At least four Shabab gunmen stormed Garissa University College, about 200 miles northeast of the capital, Nairobi, before dawn. They took students hostage and continued their assault until late in the evening, when Kenyan security forces ended the siege.

lead_paragraph: What makes a baseball record unbreakable? Sometimes the game changes and that puts a record out of reach. Sometimes an exceptional performance is too dominant to be matched. When the two combine, the record could last for centuries.

headline: The Many Droughts of California
abstract: If the sunny days continue, the state’s sunny temperament may not.
lead_paragraph: MORRO BAY, Calif. — CALIFORNIA has only two seasons, rainy and dry. In March, when the rains stop — assuming they have begun — we must forget about precipitation for at least six months. The rainfall determines our mood for the summer and fall. Where I live, on the Central Coast, 17 inches of rain per winter has been the long-term average. Beating that number — we last did it five years ago — feels like winning the lottery. Lately, the average has been well under 10.

headline: Osbornia Revisited
abstract: Getting the history right.

It’s a strange story. For the most part, as we look across the advanced world, the intellectual arguments behind the great 2010 turn to austerity have collapsed — you don’t see people invoking invisible bond vigilantes to warn of imminent crisis unless you slash spending, you don’t see them invoking the confidence fairy to deny that spending cuts will hurt output. headline: Why Evangelicals Should Love the Pope
abstract: Like Jesus, he embraces the outcast.
lead_paragraph: ON Easter Sunday, Christians celebrate an event that inspires more than two billion of the faithful with eternal hope. Jesus spoke often about the life to come. Yet he also spoke about God’s will being done here on Earth. How best to live out one’s faith in this world has been a complicated issue throughout Christian history, and it remains so today.

headline: Good Riddance, Carrie Mathison
abstract: The real women of the C.I.A. are fed up with the sodden, sexualized reel women of the C.I.A.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — THE co-creator of “Homeland” on Showtime revealed recently that when the new season starts, Claire Danes’s Carrie Mathison will no longer work at the C.I.A.

headline: The Real Reason College Tuition Costs So Much
abstract: It’s not because states have cut funding for higher education.
lead_paragraph: BOULDER, Colo. — ONCE upon a time in America, baby boomers paid for college with the money they made from their summer jobs. Then, over the course of the next few decades, public funding for higher education was slashed. These radical cuts forced universities to raise tuition year after year, which in turn forced the millennial generation to take on crushing educational debt loads, and everyone lived unhappily ever after.

headline: Thomas Cromwell, a Man for All Centuries
abstract: He was a right-hand man well versed in political skulduggery.
lead_paragraph: SUDDENLY, after 500 years of infamy and obscurity, here comes Thomas Cromwell: blacksmith’s boy, petty thief, visionary bureaucrat, shrewd banker, mercenary soldier, multilingual bagman, knife-flashing cutthroat, henchman to a cardinal and fixer for a king.

headline: Stuffed Animals With an Agenda
abstract: In Tucson, a museum celebrates trophy hunting rather than conservation.
lead_paragraph: TUCSON — ON the outskirts of this city stands a fake-medieval castle with an elk statue atop its battlements. In the courtyard is a bronze relief of a man shouldering his rifle — one C. J. McElroy, a Texan who founded both this International Wildlife Museum in 1988 and, before that, in the early 1970s, Safari Club International, the trophy hunters’ group that’s headquartered here.

headline: Forest Green Rovers Tackles Sustainability Feet First
keywords: ['Soccer', 'Stadiums and Arenas', 'Sustainable Living', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy']
abstract: For the last five years, the club’s overriding mission has been to become the self-proclaimed greenest soccer team in the world, at least off the field.
lead_paragraph: Everything about Forest Green Rovers says green, from its name to its jerseys to the rolling hills of the Cotswolds that surround the club’s home base in the Gloucestershire town of Nailsworth.

headline: Sentiments and Spaghetti
abstract: Kino! 2015, a festival of German films that begins Thursday, has drama and emotion, and let’s not forget pasta.
lead_paragraph: Kino! 2015, a festival of German films that begins Thursday, has drama and emotion, and let’s not forget pasta.

headline: Basquiat’s First Editions
abstract: Jean-Michel Basquiat returns to the Brooklyn Museum in “Basquiat: The Unknown Notebooks.”
lead_paragraph: As a kid, Jean-Michel Basquiat (1960-1988) was a junior member of the Brooklyn Museum, which he used to visit with his mother and where he got a globalist view of art history that would provide fuel for his own later painting. He’s back at the museum now, part of that global history, in “Basquiat: The Unknown Notebooks.”

headline: The Roads Never Traveled
abstract: In “100 Miles From Nowhere,” buddies travel the globe to get off the beaten path.
lead_paragraph: “Most people live their whole life on a path,” says Matt Galland, a runner and pilot who teaches geography at Brigham Young University in Utah. “My goal is to get off all paths.”

headline: Refreshening Postmodern Roots
abstract: The Stephen Petronio Company begins “Bloodlines,” a five-year project to restage important postmodern dances.
lead_paragraph: If dance seasons were like fashion weeks, then some trends from the Spring 2015 collections would be legacy projects and tributes to Merce Cunningham. Paul Taylor just ended the inaugural catwalk of his American Modern Dance initiative to preserve vintage dances and champion younger contemporary voices alongside his own. And last month brought nods to Cunningham, who died in 2009, by Compagnie CNDC-Angers from France and Juilliard Dances Repertory. This week, the Stephen Petronio Company wraps up its 30th anniversary by starting “Bloodlines,” a five-year project to restage important postmodern dances. First up: Cunningham’s “RainForest” from 1968, a work that feels both fanciful and menacing, with layers of drama, innocence and rebellion. Mr. Petronio also contributes a world premiere of his own, “Non Locomotor,” a companion to last year’s “Locomotor” (also part of this program), which confirms that three decades on, he’s still addicted to the art of speed. (Tuesday through next Sunday, Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue at 19th Street, Chelsea; 212-242-0800, joyce.org.)

headline: Victims of Financial Wrongdoing Need a More Muscular S.E.C.
keywords: ['Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis']
abstract: The regulator lacks the power to extract fines equal to the losses of harmed investors, often making class-action suits their best recourse.
lead_paragraph: Given the many billions of dollars financial companies have paid in regulatory and legal settlements related to the mortgage crisis, how much money has actually found its way into the pockets of investors harmed by their actions?

headline: Giants Who Play Well Together
abstract: Herbie Hancock and Chick Corea play at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Herbie Hancock and Chick Corea have experienced a lot of jazz history in parallel: as elite pianist-composers in post-bop’s twilight phase; as alumni of two successive Miles Davis quintets; as bandleaders who defined the arc of fusion; as artist-philosophers, National Endowment for the Arts Jazz Masters and perennial Grammy favorites. They’re also a mutual admiration society, and companionable partners, as documented on a pair of sparkling albums: “An Evening With Herbie Hancock & Chick Corea: In Concert” (Columbia) and “CoreaHancock” (Polydor).

headline: The Intimacy of Small Crowds
abstract: The adventurous Talea Ensemble plays three works by the Italian composer Pierluigi Billone.
lead_paragraph: Even chamber music often lacks intimacy in New York: Alice Tully and Zankel Halls, while smaller than some concert spaces, aren’t really ideal for trios or quartets. But two events this week deliver music for small groups at inspiringly close range. On Monday, the BAC Salon series, a program at the Baryshnikov Arts Center, presents five musicians (the oboist James Austin Smith, the violinist Tessa Lark, the violist Max Mandel, the cellist Edward Arron and the pianist Pedja Muzijevic) in an intriguing program: Mozart’s seminal Piano Quartet in G Minor, Berio’s “Sequenza VII” for oboe and the solo-piano version of Cage’s “The Seasons.” (7:30 p.m., 450 West 37th Street, Manhattan; 866-811-4111, bacnyc.org.)

headline: Do You Google Your Shrink?
abstract: Everyone seems to. And it’s changing therapy.
lead_paragraph: I knew my psychiatric practice was forever changed the day a patient arrived with a manila folder stuffed with printouts and announced that it contained the contents of a Google search that he had done on me. He pulled out a photo of my mother and me, age 7, that had been published in my hometown newspaper; architectural plans for an addition to my house that was never built but apparently was registered locally by the architect; an announcement about my great-grandfather’s becoming editor of Amazing Stories magazine in his old age; and my brother’s history as a college activist.

headline: New Music From the Mountain Goats, Joey Calderazzo, Becca Stevens Band and More
abstract: Musicians inspired by relationships, heritage and professional wrestling.
lead_paragraph: The Mountain Goats

headline: Twyla Tharp’s 50 Years of Forward Movement
abstract: Ms. Tharp reflects on a half-century of making dances, what sustains her art and how best to archive her old pieces.
lead_paragraph: In April 1965, Twyla Tharp spun a yo-yo, stretched forward like a ski jumper while anchored by a pair of wooden shoes and stood in an extended relevé. Such were the ingredients of her first piece, “Tank Dive,” which lasted around 10 minutes and was performed in an art studio at Hunter College.

headline: At the Boston Symphony, Andris Nelsons Embraces Tradition but Looks Ahead
abstract: For the moment, Mr. Nelsons is holding his interest in new works at a distance.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — Traditions are protean things. Some are ancient, some lapsed. Some are vibrant, some arid. As the historian Eric Hobsbawm pointed out, most are invented, “responses to novel situations which take on the form of reference to old situations.”

headline: Chocolations in Mamaroneck Is Frenetic in the Easter Season
abstract: In addition to handmade chocolates, Maria Valente’s shop offers items such as ice cream, handmade candles, truffle oil and truffle honey, and even a light lunch.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday afternoon, Maria Valente and members of her staff in her shop in Mamaroneck paused to consider what to name the four-foot-tall bunny standing in their midst.

headline: ILoveMakonnen Is Big Online and Almost Famous
abstract: This singer and rapper from Atlanta has a hit video with Drake and a Grammy nomination, and is setting out on his first headlining tour.
lead_paragraph: Waiting for the real world to catch up to Internet fame can be awkward, especially for a digital native accustomed to a daily cascade of favorites, retweets, streams and followers. Just ask ILoveMakonnen, the 25-year-old singer and rapper from Atlanta (best known as simply Makonnen), whose video for the hit single “Tuesday,” featuring Drake, has been seen more than 73 million times on YouTube.

headline: Italian Cuisine With Imaginative Inspirations
abstract: The originality in every course at Tazza Osteria & Bar, which opened last May in Fairfield, places it above ordinary Italian fare.
lead_paragraph: Uh-oh, I thought, as I approached the free-standing Tazza Osteria & Bar in Fairfield, yet another Italian restaurant to open in the area. Nothing new here, I anticipated. But after I opened the nondescript-looking menu I began to change my tune, and when the small plates arrived, my apprehensions had disappeared.

headline: A Move Toward Islanders Mania
abstract: For a boy whose family landed on Long Island in 1980, it was the beginning of a hockey love affair.
lead_paragraph: I left New Jersey, only to find a new jersey, a new sport and a favorite team on Long Island.

headline: A Review of H2Ocean in Cedar Knolls
abstract: H2Ocean Restaurant & Raw Bar serves only wild-caught varieties of its seafood.
lead_paragraph: Good seafood is hard to find. Restaurants that serve only wild-caught seafood are even scarcer. A happy exception, H2Ocean Restaurant & Raw Bar, which opened last August in Cedar Knolls, serves only the wild-caught variety of shrimp, scallops, salmon, tuna and other species on its varied menu.

headline: Restaurant Review: Hush Bistro in Farmingdale
abstract: The celebrity chef Marc Anthony Bynum mixes modern and retro in his hometown venture with just 28 seats.
lead_paragraph: “The food speaks” is the motto of Hush Bistro, which opened in Farmingdale in November. The attractive, thoughtfully prepared food does indeed have a voice, but people at the restaurant have not been hushed; they are part of the conversation, too.

headline: Findings Reignite Debate on Claim of Jesus’ Bones
abstract: Aryeh Shimron, a geologist based in Jerusalem, believes he has established a common bond between two Christian relics: the James burial box and the Talpiot Tomb.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Hailed by some as the most significant of all Christian relics but dismissed by skeptics amid accusations of forgery, misinterpretation and reckless speculation, two ancient artifacts found here have set off a fierce archaeological and theological debate in recent decades.

headline: Iran Will Allow Women in Sports Stadiums, Reversing a Much-Criticized Rule
abstract: Iran announced Saturday that women would be allowed to attend big sporting events, reversing a rule that had barred them from entering stadiums to watch matches attended by men.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — In a major shift, Iran announced Saturday that women would be allowed to attend big sporting events, reversing a rule that had barred them from entering stadiums to watch matches attended by men.

headline: Bronx Teenager Who Fell From Roof While Fleeing the Police Dies
abstract: Officers had chased the 17-year-old, Hakeem Kuta, after a complaint about teenagers smoking marijuana in a Bronx building lobby.
lead_paragraph: A Bronx teenager who fell off the roof of a six-story apartment building on Thursday while fleeing police officers died of his injuries on Saturday at St. Barnabas Hospital, the police said.

headline: Private Eyes in the Grocery Aisles
keywords: ['Food Contamination and Poisoning', 'Recalls and Bans of Products', 'Product Tests', 'Food']
abstract: Food suppliers, manufacturers and markets depend on testing companies like IEH Laboratories to find contaminated products and to root out fraud.
lead_paragraph: Mansour Samadpour makes his way through the supermarket like a detective working a crime scene, slow, watchful, up one aisle and down the next. A clerk mistakenly assumes that he needs help, but Mr. Samadpour brushes him off. He knows exactly what he’s doing.

headline: Washington Governor Puts Focus on Climate Goals, and Less on Debate
abstract: Working quietly, Gov. Jay Inslee is promoting an unusual plan to levy fees on carbon emissions and use the money for education and transportation.
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIA, Wash. — In his office, Gov. Jay Inslee keeps a framed image of a stand of magenta paintbrush, an alpine meadow flower and a signature species in Washington, that he photographed while hiking with his wife in Olympic National Park. The magenta paintbrush is threatened by global warming, and the photograph is a reminder, Mr. Inslee said, of all the things that are at risk.

headline: Gay Athlete Encounters Divisive Indiana Law, and Support
keywords: ['Basketball (College)', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Discrimination', 'Basketball', 'NCAA Basketball Championships (Men)']
abstract: Derrick Gordon, a guard for the University of Massachusetts, was in Indianapolis to watch the Final Four, as was Jason Collins, the retired N.B.A. center who came out as a gay in 2013.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Derrick Gordon landed here the other day, a fine guard with the University of Massachusetts, ready to watch two of the better Final Four college basketball games in recent memory.

headline: In Westchester County, Teaching Artists Aid Students in Common Core Push
abstract: A new initiative by Purchase College’s Arts in Education program aims to ensure that playtime and field trips help students meet new academic standards.
lead_paragraph: The 23 second graders in Betty Borkon’s class at George M. Davis Elementary School in New Rochelle didn’t know it, but a classroom activity in which they were pantomiming what it would be like to be desert ninjas, walking trees and stuck-to-the-ground starfish was not just playtime.

headline: A Golf Teacher With a Lion’s Instincts and a Dove’s Heart
abstract: The tale of Harvey Penick, a mild-mannered instructor who reinvigorated Ben Crenshaw’s game, may hold lessons for the struggling Tiger Woods.
lead_paragraph: Harvey Penick, the golf oracle from Texas, died 20 years ago this month, on the Sunday before the Masters. He never saw a spindly amateur named Tiger Woods make his first start that spring at Augusta National Golf Club.

headline: Choosing to Do Good, ‘Once Upon a Time’
abstract: Brecht’s “Chalk Circle” explores the strong temptation of virtue despite the pull of expediency.
lead_paragraph: Amid the armed revolution, the child abandonment, the profiteering, the threatened rape, the attempted hanging and the severed head on a stick, there is goodness. And that’s perhaps the strongest takeaway from Yale Repertory Theater’s marvelous “Caucasian Chalk Circle,” shaped into vibrant life by the director, Liz Diamond, and running through April 11 at the University Theater in New Haven.

headline: The Strip
keywords: ['Drought', 'Water', 'Rationing and Allocation of Resources', 'Comic Books and Strips']
abstract: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.
lead_paragraph: A weekly comic strip featured in the Sunday Review.

headline: A Time When the World Seemed Larger
abstract: “Come as You Are” at the Montclair Art Museum takes a look at the 1990s through works by artists in the United States.
lead_paragraph: When Nirvana was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 2014, Joan Jett was chosen to sing the group’s decade-defining hit, “Smells Like Teen Spirit,” at the ceremony. Kurt Cobain, who had written and originally performed the song — an anthem of alternative, anti-materialist subculture that had gone wildly mainstream — had killed himself in 1994. In a rare show of solidarity, the rock community almost unanimously agreed that Ms. Jett, a punk rock veteran,  was the perfect choice.

lead_paragraph: The scores you need.

headline: ‘A Chorus Line’ Revival at the John W. Engeman Theater
abstract: “A Chorus Line,” the 1975 musical about the trials of auditioning, is being performed with high energy at the John W. Engeman Theater.
lead_paragraph: “Everything was beautiful at the ballet” is one of the most recognizable song lyrics from “A Chorus Line.” A similar line, “Everything is beautiful at the theater,” could be the overall theme of the 1975 musical, which won nine Tony Awards and a Pulitzer Prize in 1976. For the characters in this show about show business, no matter the ups and often painful downs of auditioning, they are never sure they will get a job or, if they do, how long it will last.

headline: A Lift Golfers Can Get With Their Eyes Closed
abstract: To sleep specialists like Dr. Chris Winter, golfers’ attitudes and practices are as primitive as the once-standard pregame meal of steak and potatoes.
lead_paragraph: The top golfers in the world are like orchestra leaders conducting a symphony of nutritionists monitoring their food intake, trainers tailoring their workout regimens, coaches calibrating their swings, analysts crunching their statistics and psychologists decluttering their minds. The goal is to be in perfect harmony during the majors. But if the players’ circadian rhythms are off, it is akin to trying to create beautiful music with a percussion section that is a beat slow.

headline: After Shift in Nigeria, Entrenched-Party Rule Faces Test Elsewhere in Africa
abstract: An incumbent president steps down in a country with a history of military coups and rivalries, raising the possibility that it can happen elsewhere on the continent.
lead_paragraph: JOHANNESBURG — The historic election results last week in Nigeria, Africa’s most populous nation and biggest economy, drew worldwide praise and stirred hopes of a democratic domino effect on the rest of the continent.

headline: So Close and Yet So Far Away: A Round of 62 in a Major
abstract: Ever since Johnny Miller shot 63 at Oakmont in the 1973 United States Open, that number has endured as the record score in a major tournament.
lead_paragraph: Two numbers are as much a part of golf’s most popular debate as any words: 18, Jack Nicklaus’s record total of major titles, and 14, Tiger Woods’s stalled challenge.

headline: It’s a Good Time to Graduate
abstract: Employers are recruiting.
lead_paragraph: Employers are recruiting.

headline: The Captain Goes Down With the Ship
abstract: Tom McCoy turns his puzzle on its end.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY PUZZLE — There is a lot to be said for trying to see things from a different perspective. We’re used to having our crossword theme entries run across the puzzle, but turn the grid sideways so that they run down and the next thing you know, ships are sinking and “Taps” is being blown.

headline: In His Latest Novel, James Patterson Swaps Guns for Golf
abstract: The author, best known for suspense novels, has a new book, “Miracle at Augusta,” coming out just in time for this week’s Masters at Augusta National Golf Club.
lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — Nobody would accuse the author James Patterson of dawdling. He churns out books like blocks of butter.

headline: A Litmus Test for the Golden State Warriors, a Sure Thing
abstract: The Warriors have a chance to tie a record for the second-most regular-season wins in N.B.A. history, and past teams with comparable records have tended to win titles.
lead_paragraph: The Golden State Warriors, who have looked virtually incapable of losing in the regular season, will enter the N.B.A. playoffs as the team to beat. And given the teams that have performed as well in the past, they may want to get ready to celebrate.

headline: Baseball’s Milestones Map
abstract: The season begins with a number of players closing in on significant achievements. At the head of the list is Alex Rodriguez.
lead_paragraph: The season begins with a number of players closing in on significant achievements. At the head of the list is Alex Rodriguez.

headline: Apparent Saudi Strike Kills at Least Nine in Yemeni Family
abstract: The attack, part of the Saudi-led bombing campaign against the Houthi militants, may have been intended for a target a mile and a half away.
lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — At least nine people from a single family were killed when what appeared to be an airstrike by the Saudi-led military coalition struck a home in a village outside Sana, Yemen’s capital, officials said Saturday.

headline: Islamic State Seizes Palestinian Refugee Camp in Syria
abstract: Reports of killings and even beheadings were beginning to circulate, worsening what is already a longstanding humanitarian nightmare for the 18,000 residents of the Yarmouk refugee camp.
lead_paragraph: AMMAN, Jordan — Islamic State militants have seized most of a sprawling Palestinian refugee district in the southern part of the Syrian capital, Damascus, an area that has been under siege and bombardment for nearly two years already, according to Palestinian and United Nations officials and residents.

headline: Outline of Iran Nuclear Deal Sounds Different From Each Side
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'United States International Relations', 'ARMS CONTROL AND LIMITATION AND DISARMAMENT']
abstract: A review of the statements released by the United States and Iran shows some significant divisions over the terms of the accord.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Negotiators at the nuclear talks in Switzerland emerged from marathon talks on Thursday with a surprisingly detailed outline of the agreement they now must work to finalize by the end of June.

headline: Election in Scarred Ferguson Carries Hope of ‘New Tomorrow’
keywords: ['Blacks', 'Black People', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Elections, City Councils', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: Activists in Ferguson, Mo., are looking to City Council elections on Tuesday to change the face of the mostly black city’s predominantly white political leadership.
lead_paragraph: FERGUSON, Mo. — After months of racially charged unrest over the police killing of a black teenager, activists are making a final push to attract a new generation of voters to the polls on Tuesday in the hopes of changing the face of the predominantly white political leadership in this mostly black city.

headline: Robert Burns Jr., First Lynyrd Skynyrd Drummer, Dies at 64
abstract: Mr. Burns helped form Lynyrd Skynyrd, the Southern rock band, in 1964 as a drummer in high school but left 10 years later, overwhelmed by life on the road.
lead_paragraph: Robert Burns Jr., the founding drummer of Lynyrd Skynyrd, the Southern rock band known for the power ballad “Free Bird” and the anthem “Sweet Home Alabama,” died on Friday in an automobile crash in Georgia. He was 64.

abstract: You’ll surely trip over the words leader and leadership on business school websites.
lead_paragraph: You’ll surely trip over the words leader and leadership on business school websites.

headline: Fidel Castro Appears in Public for First Time in 14 Months
abstract: It was his first appearance since his brother, President Raúl Castro, and President Obama announced in December that the United States and Cuba would normalize diplomatic relations.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Former President Fidel Castro of Cuba made a surprise appearance in public for the first time in 14 months, greeting a group of Venezuelan visitors as they toured a Havana school, the Cuban news media reported on Friday.

headline: ‘Gertie’s Babies,’ Sold at Birth, Use DNA to Unlock Secret Past
abstract: Gertrude Pitkanen Van Orden delivered and sold babies, and mostly evaded legal consequence, in Montana from the 1920s through the 1950s.
lead_paragraph: COEUR D’ALENE, Idaho — Sue Docken’s start in life, in 1951, with a no-questions-asked cash adoption at the hands of a midwife, had strong elements of the crime scene that it was.

headline: Business Owners in Brooklyn Heights Start Subtle Lobbying of Clinton Campaign
abstract: As the presumptive Democratic candidate for president moves into Brooklyn Heights, the neighborhood merchants are rolling out the welcome mat.
lead_paragraph: It was a sleepy Saturday morning in Brooklyn Heights, with the post-yoga-and-brunch crowds still gathering steam for the day ahead, and Alfred Tom, an owner of The Heights Salon of Brooklyn, was carving out a pitch to his new neighbor, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

headline: Seeing a Cash Cow in Museums’ Precious Art
abstract: As budgets are pinched and business falters, public museums and companies across Europe are seeking to make ends meet by auctioning off artworks.
lead_paragraph: MÜNSTER, Germany — The director of the art museum here dreads the idea of losing some of his town’s biggest cultural attractions. He worries about a Henry Moore sculpture that has been on exhibition for almost 40 years, knowing it could vanish along with Renaissance panels and Eduardo Chillida benches in a sale to settle government debts.

headline: Masahiro Tanaka Says His Velocity May Be Lower
abstract: Tanaka, whose pitches were noticeably slower in spring training, said it was unlikely that his pitches would regain the velocity they had last season.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just about 48 hours away from throwing the first pitch of the season for the Yankees, Masahiro Tanaka issued a warning signal of sorts.

headline: Duke Shuts Down Michigan State, Advancing to N.C.A.A. Title Game
abstract: The No. 1-seeded Blue Devils, who are in the final for the first time since 2010, will be trying to secure a fifth national title for Coach Mike Krzyzewski.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — At first, the game seemed like a blowout. Then, briefly, it seemed close. Then it looked like a blowout in the other direction. That was all in the first half.

headline: Climbing the Ladder
abstract: A survey of over 12,000 business school alumni on job success and salary.
lead_paragraph: A survey of over 12,000 business school alumni on job success and salary.

headline: Jeb Bush as Inevitable Choice? Republicans Say Not So Fast
abstract: Three months into what allies once called a “shock and awe” drive to dominate the Republican presidential field, Jeb Bush’s early campaigning looks like the juggernaut that wasn’t.
lead_paragraph: Three months into what allies once confidently described as a “shock and awe” drive to overcome his rivals and dominate the Republican presidential field, Jeb Bush’s early campaigning looks like the juggernaut that wasn’t.

headline: As Serena Williams Ascends, Grand Slam Buzz Grows
abstract: It may be best not to dwell too much on Williams’s dominant victory on Saturday at the Miami Open. It is much more fun to get ahead of ourselves — perhaps way ahead of ourselves.
lead_paragraph: KEY BISCAYNE, Fla. — The women’s final between Serena Williams and Carla Suárez Navarro on Saturday at the Miami Open was predictably brutal and mercifully brief.

headline: Dortmund Romps to 6-0, Rising as a Kentucky Derby Favorite
abstract: Dortmund overcame a stumble out of the gate to lead every step of the way in an emphatic victory at the Santa Anita Derby, and remained undefeated.
lead_paragraph: ARCADIA, Calif. — Call it Selection Saturday — three important prep races run in a stretch of 90 minutes to determine which horses have a realistic chance to capture the 140th running of the Kentucky Derby next month. When it was over, there was little doubt about the overwhelming favorite at this moment.

headline: A Norway Town and Its Pipeline to Jihad in Syria
abstract: After at least eight young men from a single neighborhood in Norway left for Syria, local officials were left pondering: Why it is that certain areas generate a disproportionate number of jihadists?
lead_paragraph: FREDRIKSTAD, Norway — The real trouble started when they stopped causing trouble. Torleif Sanchez Hammer and his friends — all residents of the same small cluster of clapboard houses in southern Norway — had been having run-ins with the police for years but then suddenly halted their marijuana-fueled gatherings in the basement apartment of Mr. Hammer’s widowed mother.

headline: Indiana Residents Rue Damage to State’s Welcoming Reputation
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Freedom of Religion', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: As a religious exception law divided Indiana, there was a more general agreement that the debate had tarnished the state’s reputation for magnanimity and friendliness.
lead_paragraph: MARTINSVILLE, Ind. — Michelle Crafton, the owner of a tiny bakery in this struggling town 30 miles south of Indianapolis, is not sure what she would do if asked to cater a same-sex wedding.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, April 5, 2015
abstract: Quotation of the day for Sunday, April 5, 2015.
lead_paragraph: “We wondered what had happened but were glad when they dropped off our radar.”

headline: ‘Outlander’ Recap: The Show Takes a New Point of View
abstract: The show returns from its long hiatus, and we see things through Jamie’s eyes.
lead_paragraph: Season 1, Episode 9: “The Reckoning”

headline: Final Tweaks to Mets’ Roster Made With Higher Aspirations
abstract: Dillon Gee’s selection as the fifth starter was among the moves completed with the postseason firmly in mind.
lead_paragraph: In recent years, as spring training wound down and the Mets debated who would fill out their bullpen, their bench and the back of their rotation, it often felt as if they were rearranging the deck chairs on a sinking ship.

headline: Wisconsin Ends Kentucky’s Undefeated Streak and Will Face Duke for N.C.A.A. Title
abstract: The Badgers handed the Wildcats their first loss of the season and advanced to the university’s first title game since 1941.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — It was here, finally, after 364 days — long enough for Kentucky to reload and to rewrite history and for Wisconsin to reconcile its paralyzing defeat on this stage a year ago, or at least come close.

headline: After Starting Slowly, L.P.G.A. Veterans Make a Push
abstract: After the early rounds of the ANA Inspiration, in which youngsters seized the advantage, four former champions played their way into contention in Round 3.
lead_paragraph: RANCHO MIRAGE, Calif. — The youth gale that blew a layer of pixie dust on the ANA Inspiration died down Saturday, and a few seasoned pros cleared a trail up the leaderboard. Led by the ageless Australian Karrie Webb, a two-time champion, four former winners of this event played their way into contention during the third round at Mission Hills Country Club.

headline: Henrik Lundqvist Nears Top Form; Rangers Near Top Seed
abstract: Lundqvist made 35 saves against the Devils in his best game since returning from a neck injury.

The historical drama, presented here by “Masterpiece,” begins as Cardinal Thomas Wolsey (Jonathan Pryce, above right with Mr. Rylance), having failed to secure the annulment of the marriage of Henry (Damian Lewis) to Katherine of Aragon (Joanne Whalley), is stripped of his powers — placing his hope of returning to the king’s favor on Cromwell. Based on two Booker Prize winners and starring Mr. Rylance, one of the great stage actors of our time, “it’s acutely intelligent, luxuriously dressed and well acted across the board,” Mike Hale wrote in The New York Times. “It’s also notably serious and quiet, despite the occasional beheading or session on the rack.”

Mr. Glass was then a precocious freshman at the University of Chicago and taking the first steps on the path to becoming a composer. When he learned of a new recording of the complete Schoenberg string quartets played by the Juilliard String Quartet, he ordered four copies. Aghast, his father asked if he was trying to put him out of business. To teach his son a lesson, he told him to put the recordings of these atonal chamber works on the shelves with the more mainstream classical records and report back when the last copy had been sold. That took seven years. The lesson Mr. Glass learned? “I can sell anything if I have enough time.”

headline: Iran and the Obama Doctrine
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Nuclear Weapons', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In an interview with Thomas L. Friedman, President Obama discussed the calculations that informed the Iran nuclear framework and what they say about his overall approach to foreign policy.
lead_paragraph: In September 1996, I visited Iran. One of my most enduring memories of that trip was that in my hotel lobby there was a sign above the door proclaiming “Down With USA.” But it wasn’t a banner or graffiti. It was tiled and plastered into the wall. I thought to myself: “Wow — that’s tiled in there! That won’t come out easily.” Nearly 20 years later, in the wake of a draft deal between the Obama administration and Iran, we have what may be the best chance to begin to pry that sign loose, to ease the U.S.-Iran cold/hot war that has roiled the region for 36 years. But it is a chance fraught with real risks to America, Israel and our Sunni Arab allies: that Iran could eventually become a nuclear-armed state.

But at least the gullible Eve and her mate had to cope with just the one snake. In South Florida, wildlife officials have struggled for years with tens of thousands of the creatures: specifically, a species known as the Burmese python, an interloper from Southeast Asia that has taken up what looks like permanent residence in Everglades National Park and other areas of the state.

headline: Old Haunt of U.S. Spies Becomes a Playground for Istanbul’s Elite
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The United States has become the landlord to the private club empire Soho House, as part of a deal initially intended to keep a historic building as a space to foster relations with the Middle East.
lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — For more than a century, the grand Italianate mansion that serves as an anchor of this city’s European quarter was a beehive of American diplomacy and espionage. Spies toiled within and met their agents at the bar across the street, reporters dropped by for after-work drinks, and any Turk could walk in off the street to see the latest art exhibition or browse the library. There seemed to be a celebration every night.

Less than an hour earlier, the Badgers had ended Kentucky’s 38-game winning streak and avenged a heartbreaking loss to the Wildcats in a national semifinal last year.

Brush Stairway, an obscure spot near where the Polo Grounds once stood, named for the long-ago owner of the New York Giants baseball team. headline: The Luxury of Leftovers
abstract: Feasting on food scraps from Greenwich Village to Milan, as waste becomes a dirty word.

During Expo Milano 2015, the Michelin-starred chef Massimo Bottura will oversee — with help from Mario Batali, Alain Ducasse and René Redzepi — the Ambrosian Refectory, a pop-up dining hall in a disused theater, where meals will be made using surplus from the estimated 400 tons of food that arrive at the culinary fair each day. Batali and Ducasse also recently worked at New York’s wastED, a temporary restaurant at Dan Barber’s Blue Hill in Greenwich Village, which involved a cast of rotating chefs addressing food waste in their menus. In England, Thomasina Miers of the popular Mexican chain Wahaca is championing the Pig Idea, which proposes to change European law to allow for the leftover food of restaurants and catering companies to be used as pig and chicken feed.

headline: What’s On TV Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8:10 P.M. (Starz Cinema) THE LUNCHBOX (2014) When a delivery service sends a lunch intended for her husband astray, a neglected Mumbai housewife (Nimrat Kaur, above left, with Yashvi Puneet Nagar) finds herself communicating through handwritten letters and home-cooked meals with a widowed office worker (Irrfan Khan) nearing retirement in this debut feature from Ritesh Batra. “This is not a new conceit,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times, citing “You’ve Got Mail” and “The Shop Around the Corner.” But, he wrote, “the idea of two lonely souls connecting in a vast, modern metropolis, and remaining strangers even as their intimacy grows, has a durable charm. As do Mr. Khan and Ms. Kaur, islands of melancholy calm surrounded by silliness and noise. Their performances are not exactly subtle — nothing in ‘The Lunchbox’ is exactly subtle — but they are graceful and dignified in the manner of movie stars in an earlier, less aggressive age, ennobling the ordinary lives they explore. And Mr. Batra makes their story touching and credible, an urban fable of hope in the face of disappointment.”

That agreement was imperfect. Still, not another shot was fired in anger after the loss of more than 100,000 lives. This accord, too, reflects harsh realities — Iran has mastered the nuclear fuel cycle — yet represents the best possibility by far of holding Iran short of a bomb, ring-fencing its nuclear capacities, coaxing change in the Islamic Republic, and ushering a hopeful society closer to the world. If the yardstick is effectiveness, and it must be, no conceivable alternative even comes close. Perfection is not part of diplomacy’s repertoire.

headline: Creatures of the Wind and Tavi Gevinson’s Southern Spring Trip
abstract: The designer duo and 18-year-old multihyphenate traveled to Charlotte, North Carolina, to fete the arrival of the label’s seasonal designs at a local boutique.
lead_paragraph: Last September at Creatures of the Wind’s spring/summer 2015 fashion show, the 18-year-old multihyphenate wonder Tavi Gevinson sat front row and said to John Kobin for The New York Times, “It’s really nice to see it and also to drop in as an observer.” And late last week, she saw it again — this time, in North Carolina, where she co-hosted a dinner with the design duo, Shane Gabier and Christopher Peters, to celebrate the collection’s arrival at the Capitol boutique there. “Tavi has been a friend of ours since the Chicago days; she’s one of the coolest people we know,” Gabier says. “We hadn’t been able to hang out much this year, so it was great to have a few days together in Charlotte to catch up.” During their stay down South, the three amigos ate top-notch Carolina BBQ and shared a screened-in sleeping porch at the hundred-year-old mansion they called home for a few days. Here, Gabier and Peters recount highlights from their trip.

headline: Forest Fires Threaten New Fallout From Chernobyl

headline: Georgia: Judge Sets Hearing on Request by Transgender Inmate for Transfer
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexuals', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Sex Crimes', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: A federal district judge on Monday set a hearing for Thursday on an emergency motion in the case of a transgender woman, Ashley Diamond, who is seeking an immediate transfer to a lower-security prison or “transitional center” so that she can be safer from sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: A federal district judge on Monday set a hearing for Thursday on an emergency motion in the case of a transgender woman, Ashley Diamond, who is seeking an immediate transfer to a lower-security prison or “transitional center” so that she can be safer from sexual assault. Judge Marc T. Treadwell also asked Georgia corrections officials to produce all communications — “emails, correspondence, messages, etc.” — regarding Ms. Diamond’s transfer several weeks ago to Georgia State Prison. Ms. Diamond alleges that the transfer, to a prison with a relatively high prevalence of sexual violence, was “apparently retaliatory” for her lawsuit against corrections officials. Ms. Diamond, 36, is a nonviolent offender and first-time inmate who has lived as a transgender woman since adolescence, but has been held in prisons for men, most of them high-security, for the last three years. She claims in her lawsuit to have suffered at least seven sexual assaults as well as routine sexual coercion and harassment. In addition to safer housing, her lawsuit, filed in February, seeks access to the hormone therapy that is essential medical care for her gender dysphoria. She had been taking hormones for 17 years, she says, until the prison system denied her access. A Georgia corrections spokeswoman said on Monday that Ms. Diamond “has been receiving the appropriate treatment assessed by Georgia Correction Health medical staff” since March. This is apparently a reference to a hormone patch given to her in response to her lawsuit.

headline: What It Really Means to Call Hillary Clinton ‘Polarizing’

abstract: If there is one thing that unites American voters, it’s our love of charging politicians with being divisive.
lead_paragraph: Late in George W. Bush’s first term, the conservative commentator Charles Krauthammer coined the term “Bush Derangement Syndrome,” which he defined as “the acute onset of paranoia in otherwise normal people in reaction to the policies, the presidency — nay — the very existence of George W. Bush.” In other words, there were a whole bunch of people, presumably on the left, who not only didn’t like George W. Bush, but also disliked him to an irrational and perhaps unhinged degree. By coining a “syndrome” to describe the state, Krauthammer, a formerly practicing psychiatrist with an M.D. from Harvard, was injecting a clever bit of gas-lighting into the debate. (Are you sure there’s not something else going on with you, Bush haters? Have you considered getting help?)

headline: The Living Beauty of Wicken Fen
abstract: In one of Britain’s oldest nature reserves, Darwin collected beetles and Saxon warlords hid from invaders. But walking there now is much more than a visit to the past.
lead_paragraph: On a foggy morning last spring, I took my brother and 11-year-old niece for a long walk in one of Britain’s oldest nature reserves, Wicken Fen, a tiny fragment of a lost marshland ecosystem that once covered around 2,500 square miles of eastern England. We spent hours walking through a mosaic of grassland and sedge, past wet fields cut with scrub-shadow and flashes of open water. Everywhere was bursting with life: singing nightingales, snipe winnowing through the upper air, cuckoos tilting from the tips of willows and rails squealing and grunting in reeds. As we walked on wet grass by one of the fen’s ancient waterways, a barn owl floated past us, its mothy wings shining through particulate mist; at our feet a drinker moth caterpillar inched furrily across the path like a cautiously mobile mustache. We knelt to watch its progress. Then my niece turned to me and asked: “When they made this place, where did they bring the animals from? Did they come from a zoo?”

abstract: A “biography” of the only concentration camp built primarily to hold female prisoners.

headline: Another ‘Serial’ Chapter, From Group of Lawyers
abstract: Starting Monday a group of lawyers and advocates connected to Adnan Syed, the subject of the podcast “Serial,” will debut another podcast, “Undisclosed: The State v. Adnan Syed.”
lead_paragraph: The story behind the hit podcast “Serial” is not over. The podcast focused on the 1999 death of Hae Min Lee, a Maryland teenager, and the subsequent conviction of her former boyfriend, Adnan Syed, who is serving a life sentence for murder. It became the fastest podcast to reach five million downloads, according to Apple. Starting Monday a group of lawyers and advocates connected to Mr. Syed will debut another podcast, “Undisclosed: The State v. Adnan Syed,” which will “examine and explore the case in greater detail, from an investigatory perspective instead of a narrative one,” according to a statement. “Undisclosed” is being presented by Rabia Chaudry, a lawyer who has been a longtime advocate of Mr. Syed — as “Serial” fans know, she was the one who suggested that Sarah Koenig, the host of “Serial” and a longtime producer for “This American Life,” look into the case — along with two other lawyers, Susan Simpson and Colin Miller. None of them represent Mr. Syed but each has been investigating the case, Ms. Chaudry said in an interview Tuesday. New episodes of “Undisclosed” are to be released every two weeks. The podcast is sponsored by the Adnan Syed Legal Trust, which, according to a page on the crowdfunding site LaunchGood, is dedicated to Mr. Syed’s defense and has raised $93,000. In November the producers of “Serial” said that a second season was coming. In February a Maryland court agreed to hear an appeal from Mr. Syed, who has said that he is not guilty of Ms. Lee’s murder and that he received ineffective legal counsel at trial.

lead_paragraph: Gunmen ambushed a Jalisco State police convoy, killing 15 officers in one of the deadliest attacks on security forces in eight years of the drug war, state officials said Tuesday. The convoy was attacked as the police units were traveling through the remote western mountains of Jalisco toward Guadalajara. The gunmen are believed to belong to a powerful gang called the New Generation Jalisco Cartel, Jalisco’s security commissioner, Alejandro Solorio Aréchiga, said Tuesday in a radio interview. A man suspected of being one of the gang’s leaders, Heriberto Acevedo Cárdenas, was killed in a shootout with security forces on March 23. Four days earlier, 11 people were killed when a federal police convoy was attacked in Jalisco.

headline: More Teens Using Long-Term Contraception
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Teenagers and Adolescence']
abstract: The use of long-acting, reversible birth control like intrauterine devices and implants has risen sharply among teenagers in the last decade, new federal data show.
lead_paragraph: The use of long-acting, reversible birth control like intrauterine devices and implants has risen sharply among teenagers in the last decade, new federal data show. Researchers from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention studied the use of such contraceptives at clinics that receive federal money under the Title X program, which focuses on low-income adults and teenagers. About eight million young women ages 15 to 19 sought birth control at the clinics from 2005 to 2013. At the beginning of the study period, just 0.4 percent, or about 4,000, were using long-term birth control. By 2013, the researchers reported, that had risen to 7 percent, or about 40,000 teenagers. Federal officials say that although long-acting birth control is by far the most effective method, its use among women over all still lags, and they are encouraging providers to take steps to increase the numbers.

headline: Visually Arresting Graphic Rugs That Value Asymmetry (So as Not to Compete With God)
abstract: A new limited-edition capsule collection by the art director Alex Proba and the textile designer Aelfie Oudghiri arrives at Shop Cooper Hewitt on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The art director Alex Proba (of StudioProba, A Poster A Day and Kickstarter) and the rug and textile designer Aelfie Oudghiri (of Aelfie) are two of a kind — both create colorful, arrestingly graphic work; originally studied to be doctors in Europe; and are pillars of the collab-happy Brooklyn design community. And so one thing led to another, and a new series of limited-edition rugs and other decorative items, debuting Monday at Shop Cooper Hewitt, was born. The five rug styles ($1,675 each) and three pillow designs ($105 each), hand-dyed and -loomed in the Uttar Pradesh region of northern India, take cues from Kurdish weaving motifs and early Internet graphics, and feature hand-knotting techniques that make them look, Proba says, “more 3D than they actually are.” Many are asymmetrical, like the designs in Proba’s poster series: “That’s one of the reasons I was excited about her work, because you have to work at looking at it,” Oudghiri explains. “That’s a huge tenet of rug weaving; you keep things asymmetrical as a form of humility because you don’t want to compete with God.” And for those who might be, as Proba puts it, “afraid to commit” to the high-impact textiles, the shop will also be selling posters ($155) of the original flat designs.

Boyle’s 15th novel, takes on the paranoia of the far-right sovereign citizen movement and off-the-grid/mountain-man survivalism, as well as more mainstream American notions of independence. This could easily have been an opportunity for a writer of Boyle’s comic gifts to go full-tilt satirical, but Boyle takes a darker and more ­restrained approach. He has written a compelling, complex and intimate novel about three particular people in a specific time and place, a novel that tells us something unnerving about certain precincts of the American Now.

It is, of course, natural territory for the novel, and though Ann Packer’s “The Children’s Crusade” follows one nuclear family, its scope is broadened by its attempts at an answer.

headline: The Radical Vision of Toni Morrison
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Writing and Writers', 'Book Trade and Publishing']
abstract: At 84, she sits comfortably as one of the greatest authors in American history, even as her uncompromising dream for black literature seems farther away than ever.
lead_paragraph: Not too long ago, Toni Morrison sat in the small kitchen attached to the studio where she was recording the audiobook for her newest novel, “God Help the Child,” telling a roomful of strangers stories that I will never forget. The studio, a small, refurbished barn in Katonah, N.Y., was more than a hundred years old, but only a few rustic touches remained, like a sliding barn door and knotty pine floors. A solid kitchen table had been laid with fresh fruits, muffins and tins of jam. Beams of sunlight reflected off the blindingly white snow outside the glass window. A young woman from Random House kept mentioning her sunglasses, how it was bright enough to wear them inside. Everyone giggled at her nervous chatter, but they seemed to be mostly laughing at her brave attempt to make small talk in the presence of Toni Morrison.

headline: Love and Loss
abstract: Two new picture books celebrate parental devotion, tinged with mortality.
lead_paragraph: In children’s books, parental love can be a surprisingly hot-potato subject. Take the latest round of debate over Shel Silverstein’s classic “The Giving Tree.” Is the book’s depiction of all-in maternal self-sacrifice beautiful, or disturbing and patriarchal? Impassioned arguments persist on both sides. That split recalls similar objections to Robert Munsch’s “Love You Forever,” first published in 1986, which features a new mother rocking her baby and singing a little song that ends, “As long as I’m living / my baby you’ll be.” She repeats the song as she snuggles up to her child through his childhood and teenage years, and even when he is a grown man. Some see in the tale a straightforward, reassuring depiction of the boundlessness of a parent’s love. Others think it’s just too smothering and creepy, especially the way the woman crawls into her adult son’s bed.

headline: 36 Hours in Antigua, Guatemala
abstract: The 500-year-old city feels like a portal to another century, with a wealth of colonial architecture, markets, ruins and rain forest.
lead_paragraph: Less than an hour away from the concrete sprawl of Guatemala City, Antigua feels like a portal to another century. The nearly 500-year-old city is cradled by three volcanoes and filled with colonial-era mansions, churches and convents, many with orange and yellow facades. In the evening, residents gather in the jacaranda-lined plazas to listen to musicians tapping mallets on marimbas, or wander between lively night spots. Once the capital of this Central American country (before a series of devastating earthquakes forced the colonial government to move to Guatemala City in the late 1700s), Antigua, population 41,000, is a Unesco World Heritage site. Yet in addition to the striking 17th- and 18th-century ruins right in the center of town, the city offers an array of restaurants, boutiques and bars with live music. Visitors can browse the craft markets or sip an espresso at a working coffee farm, while those with a more adventurous streak can hike up one of the looming volcanoes, or strap on a helmet, lock in a carabiner and hurtle through the rain forest on a zip wire.

lead_paragraph: “Antonioni Was Here,” announces a Julian Schnabel painting at the entrance of the exhibition “Antonioni: Aux Origines du Pop,” which runs tomorrow through July 19 at La Cinémathèque Française. Indeed, the iconic filmmaker left an indelible mark. “He was an explorer, an inventor, a man in perpetual inquiétude regarding the cinematographic form,” remarks Serge Toubiana, the director of the Cinémathèque, which is also hosting a complete filmic retrospective running through May 31. Toubiana cites the sense of “narrative shock, aesthetic shock” Antonioni brought to cinema — whether featuring a fashion photographer modeled on David Bailey in the swinging London of “Blow Up” or casting the exquisite Monica Vitti in a trio of films (“L’Avventura,” “La Notte,” “L’Eclisse”) about indefinable human malaise. Although never quite celebrated or completely understood in his native Italy, he won accolades internationally, some of which are displayed in the exhibition, including a Palme d’Or from 1967, and an honorary Oscar from 1995 (represented by a mislabeled replica, as the original was stolen during a burglary).

headline: A Revived New Orleans Market Champions the Local and Brightens Up the Neighborhood
abstract: Thanks to damage from Hurricane Katrina, it took three years and $3.7 million to restore the historic St. Roch Market, which opens today.
lead_paragraph: Urban European-style food halls packed with grab-and-go artisanal goods and gourmet groceries from specialty purveyors and local vendors are quickly becoming commonplace across America. A majority of these stateside culinary wonderlands are located, of course, in Manhattan: This spring has already welcomed downtown’s Le District, a vast 30,000-square-foot French market near the World Trade Center (commonly dubbed the “French Eataly”) and a new Times Square multi-vendor called City Kitchen. And modern markets of all sizes are set to open between now and early fall, from Seattle (Market Hall) to Portland (Pine Street Market), Denver (Avanti Food and Beverage) to Atlanta (Ponce City Market) and Charleston (The Cigar Factory). Today, New Orleans joins the trend with the reopening of St. Roch Market — in its original building, which was wrecked by Hurricane Katrina nearly a decade ago.

headline: What’s on TV Thursday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (FX) THE COMEDIANS Billy Crystal is a comedy legend whose best work may be behind him and Josh Gad is a rising star in this new series, which ventures behind the scenes at “The Billy & Josh Show,” a semifictional late-night sketch series. Stephnie Weir plays the long-suffering producer caught between the men, who agree on almost nothing; Matt Oberg is the show’s head writer; and Megan Ferguson is the no-nonsense production assistant. “Semifake Billy and semifake Josh drop references to these real-life résumés constantly in ‘The Comedians’ as they try to one-up each other while battling over the show they’re supposed to be creating together,” Neil Genzlinger wrote in The New York Times. How meta is it? In Episode 4, Mel Brooks “advises his friend Billy not to try to book a big-name guest on ‘The Billy & Josh Show’ because it would distract the audience from the title characters. Mr. Brooks, of course, steals the episode.” In the Season 5 opener of “Louie,” at 10:30, Louie (Louis C.K.) admits in therapy that he’s not sure “how to live a life anymore” and encounters an angry lesbian at a school potluck. “This time around, as Louis C.K. reinvents the classic sitcom in his own elliptical, cerebral style, he seems to be in his absurdist theater phase, or his surrealist short-story phase — Kafka on the Hudson,” Mike Hale wrote in The Times. “His moments of victory, and redemption, come when he’s alone, onstage, working a funny voice and a dumb joke.”

One of the first homegrown national fads to go global, the cakewalk anticipated the paroxysms of twerking that would follow, whose late adopters like Miley Cyrus might be forgiven for missing the deep irony in the form’s black origins.

headline: Morning Agenda: The $100 Billion Deal Day
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Stocks and Bonds', 'Venture Capital']
abstract: The $100 Billion Deal Day| Goldman’s Coup| Back in the Game at Zynga
lead_paragraph: THE $100 BILLION DEAL DAY  | Two huge offers – one accepted, the other unsolicited – trumpet a potential new frenzy of activity in deal-making. First and foremost, Royal Dutch Shell’s $70 billion acquisition of BG Group of Britain signals that the kinds of behemoth energy mergers that reshaped the industry in the late 1990s may be due for a revival in the face of lower oil and gas prices. In energy, the Brontosaurus is back. Mylan’s $29 billion approach to Perrigo, meanwhile, underscores just how red-hot consolidation in health care continues to be. Both of the generic drug makers had done their own deals in just the last two years.

headline: How Low Can the Philadelphia 76ers Go?
abstract: On the road with pro basketball’s lovable losers.
lead_paragraph: There has never been a professional sports team quite like the 2014-15 Philadelphia 76ers, a roster of basketball castoffs and drifters that could be the least capable assemblage of players ever to suit up for an N.B.A. game. The franchise — widely believed by those who follow pro basketball to be deliberately in “tank mode,” in order to lose games and get a top pick in this summer’s N.B.A. draft — has offended sensibilities, provoked curiosity, inspired bizarre mathematical theorems. How low could they go? After they lost 17 games to open the current season, the FiveThirtyEight website published a “dark simulation” that projected their losing streak could reach 54 games. Deadspin declared the Sixers a “godless abomination,” while Slam Magazine, the hip-hop basketball bible, described them as a “flesh-eating bacteria of sorts on the N.B.A.’s collective self-respect.”

Too often, especially around this time of year, that conversation centers on college or the kinds of academics and activities that lead to college. “Success” is hard to measure, and those external markers make for comforting milestones along the way.

headline: Julia Louis-Dreyfus and Tony Hale’s Demented Double Act on ‘Veep’
abstract: The HBO comedy is a caustic political satire. But its true core is the singularly awkward, brutal, tender, nonromantic romance between Selina and Gary.
lead_paragraph: The show begins — the very first scene of the very first episode — with a man helping a woman put on her coat. The man is tall. The woman is small. The man is balding. The woman has the shimmering hair of an extremely convincing shampoo ad. The man wears a nondescript dark suit, a striped tie and some kind of ID badge — the uniform of the bureaucratic functionary. He has a five o’clock shadow and the hint of a double chin. The woman wears a snug red dress with a deep neckline, an elegant gold necklace, understated makeup. She is the vice president of the United States. Getting her coat on is therefore an official matter of state, and the man is clearly treating it as such; he concentrates intently on maneuvering her right arm into the coat’s right sleeve. The woman, meanwhile, pays no attention to the man or to the coat, never even glances back; she stares forward, into the eyes of her chief of staff, with whom she is having a conversation.

headline: Iris Apfel Doesn’t Do Normcore

lead_paragraph: You’ve been a mainstay of the New York fashion scene for years, and you’re now the subject of a documentary, “Iris,” directed by Albert Maysles. Considering how long you’ve been around, are you surprised at all the recent interest in your life? It seems insane to me. I’m doing nothing different than what I’ve done for the last 70-odd years. Maybe I was ahead of the game, and people caught up with me. There aren’t too many 93-year-old cover girls around.

headline: Ana Khouri’s Newest Jewelry Forms — to Accentuate a Woman’s Own
abstract: The designer introduces her latest pieces on live models today at Dover Street Market.
lead_paragraph: The Brazilian designer Ana Khouri’s fine jewelry isn’t defined by carats, cut or color, nor by its high-profile fans, like Madonna and Jennifer Lawrence. Instead, she aims to distinguish her work by highlighting its natural synergy with the human anatomy. In her latest designs (she doesn’t create collections), the former art scholar and sculptor is taking that notion, of connecting the accessory to its wearer, even further. Today at Dover Street Market New York, she debuts collar necklaces, earrings, rings and bracelets made from materials like yellow gold, pavé diamonds and pearls. “I was inspired by a dialogue with the human form,” Khouri says. “The shapes of these pieces follow the lines of the body.” There are cuffs that appear to climb inside the ear and slink their way out of the lobe, and rings that “better frame the curves of the fingers.” Inspired by artists like Louise Bourgeois and Alberto Giacometti, Khouri explains that she aims to “call attention to the lines of the thing — and not the person who is wearing it.” To that effect, the DSMNY installation features live models, veiled and wearing the pieces over their fabric-draped skin — so that viewers only, as Khouri puts it, “focus only on what is essential.”

Few Dallasites are busier this week than collector Christen Wilson. In addition to chairing Dallas’s Nasher Sculpture Center’s program committee and sitting on similar councils for the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York and London’s Tate museum, she and her husband Derek regularly open their museum-like Highland Park home to visitors and local art lovers alike. Last night, they hosted a reception for the Dallas Museum of Art, amid collection highlights from Sterling Ruby to Donald Judd and Eddie Peake on view. Here, Wilson shares her favorite spots around town — for Art Week or anytime.

headline: A Honey Lozenge of a Cocktail for Cold Spring Days
abstract: Manhattan’s Saxon and Parole shares a recipe for spiked bergamot tea.
lead_paragraph: The sharp lens of Bill Cunningham revealed that by the end of March, we still hadn’t shaken our winter black-and-whites. And this week, meteorologists predicted rain every day for the Big Apple — and rain it has. With restaurants reluctant to open up their gardens and sidewalk seating, New Yorkers have yet to savor that first al fresco drink of the season. Indoors, the Bowery’s Saxon & Parole is passing the time until warmer weather arrives with the bartender Maxime Belfand’s Laddie Punch, a surprisingly light drink that warms the bones (thanks to bergamot tea) but isn’t too heavy for April attitudes. “Wintertime, we tend to use heavier spices like cinnamon or even anise or nutmeg,” says Belfand, adding that in the summer, we crave a drink “that has light botanicals in it.” The addition of lemon and vermouth puts his Scotch-based summer drink somewhere between a Rob Roy and a honey lozenge, perfect for the rain-soaked bon vivant.

headline: Review: ‘Coypel’s Don Quixote Tapestries’ Weaves a Classic Tale
abstract: An exhibition at the Frick Collection is devoted to a set of mural-scale tapestries depicting episodes from the novel that were created in Paris.
lead_paragraph: Miguel de Cervantes’s “Don Quixote,” whose first volume was published in 1605, has inspired and challenged illustrators from Goya to Dalí. Few have captured the paradoxical essence of a book in which fantasy and reality collide to farcical effect over and over. It’s a hard problem: How would you picture simultaneously the narrator’s vividly realistic, warts-and-all description of his hapless protagonist’s adventures and Don Quixote’s own delusional view of himself as a knight errant in a simplified world of heroes, villains, giants and damsels in distress? How would you make visible such a contradictory double vision?

In “Ex Machina,” Alex Garland’s slyly spooky futuristic shocker about old and new desires, the female in question is a robot called Ava, a name suggestive of both Adam and Eve. Ava has a serene humanoid face and the expressive hands and feet of a dancer, but also the transparent figure of a visible woman anatomy model. Beautiful and smart, sleek and stacked, Ava is at once decidedly unsettling and safely under lock and key, which makes her an ideal posthuman female.
