headline: Microsoft (Yes, Microsoft) Has a Far-Out Vision
abstract: The reshaped Microsoft that Satya Nadella, the new chief executive, envisions has fewer internal fiefs and is more willing to favor big bets on new technologies over protecting legacy cash cows.
lead_paragraph: Last June, in the basement of the Microsoft visitor center in Redmond, Wash., Todd Holmdahl, a Microsoft hardware guru, and others nervously walked Satya Nadella, the new chief executive, through a demonstration of a secret project.

headline: Paris Photo L.A.’s Favorite Couple Shares Their Hometown Haunts
abstract: The Italian art patrons Pierpaolo Barzan and Valeria Sorci recently moved to California and have found plenty to do (and share).
lead_paragraph: “I surf,” Pierpaolo Barzan says. In fact, it’s one of the first details imparted by the Italian art patron — one-half of the Depart Foundation, alongside his wife Valeria Sorci, the two of whom recently moved to Los Angeles. “I think he went just for the surfing!,” Sorci quips. But in truth, the couple had been coming to L.A. regularly for five years, and decided to move when they realized, as Sorci puts it, that “it was getting harder to leave!” So the partners in life, love and art packed up from Rome and began a new chapter in California, which now includes an exhibition space in West Hollywood and a storied home in the Hollywood Hills — an “old Tudor house that belonged to the actress Anne Baxter,” Sorci explains. “She was the granddaughter of Frank Lloyd Wright, so she asked her grandfather to do some remodeling.” Wright started, “and then passed the job to John Lautner.”

headline: In Iran, Fatal Porsche Crash Unleashes Middle-Class Anger at Elites
abstract: The recent deaths of two youths in a Porsche earned scorn, not sympathy, in Iran, where luxury cars are symbols of growing inequality between the 1 percenters and the middle classes.
lead_paragraph: TEHRAN — It was 5 o’clock on a recent morning as the canary yellow Porsche raced up the treelined Shariati boulevard in Tehran. The young woman at the wheel, it later emerged, came from the poorer south side of the city. The young man next to her, the nouveau riche grandson of an ayatollah, had bought the car just two days earlier.

headline: Hillary Clinton Expected to Treat Bernie Sanders Gingerly
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Bernie Sanders’s message — including the degree to which he described himself as a “leader” in the fight against the Iraq war, which Hillary Rodham Clinton voted for — highlighted why she will likely need to treat him with deference.
lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont says he is running for president to win. His campaign announcement — a short news conference outdoors in Washington before he darted back to work — was a study in contrast with Hillary Rodham Clinton, who has yet to greet the press since announcing her candidacy.

headline: War, Repentance and Japan
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has begun to address Japan’s occupation of China and Korea, but critics say he must do more.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan carries a huge burden as his country marks the 70th anniversary of its defeat in World War II this year. He is clearly enthusiastic about charting a future that expands Japan’s  alliance with America in economic and security affairs.

headline: Salesforce’s Slow Growth May Prompt Hunt for a Buyer
abstract: Oracle and Microsoft want to increase cloud capacity, making them possible suitors.
lead_paragraph: Salesforce.com’s slowing growth makes this a good time to seek a suitor. The $47 billion software outfit is on the market, according to Bloomberg.

headline: Times Reporters Analyze Bernie Sanders’s Presidential Campaign Remarks
abstract: Two New York Times correspondents, Patrick Healy and Maggie Haberman, discussed Mr. Sanders’s remarks about his priorities for the country and his challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the 2016 Democratic nomination.
lead_paragraph: Announcing his candidacy for president on Thursday, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont chose a grassy spot outside the Capitol to hold a 10-minute news conference about his priorities for the country and his challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton for the 2016 Democratic nomination. Over instant messages at noon, two New York Times correspondents, Patrick Healy and Maggie Haberman, analyzed Mr. Sanders’s remarks. Here, lightly edited, is their full chat.

headline: Proposal to Arm Sunnis Adds to Iraqi Suspicions of the U.S.
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Sunni Muslims', 'Shiite Muslims', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: After congressional Republicans floated a plan to arm Iraqi Sunnis and Kurds directly, the country was outraged and saw a plot to divide their country.
lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Despite stepped-up military assistance to Iraq to fight Islamic State militants, and President Obama’s public commitment to keeping Iraq unified, Iraqis have long suspected a nefarious plot by the Americans to break up their country.

headline: Nepal Survivors Lay Amid Rubble and Bodies After Earthquake
abstract: After a cry from within the rubble, a boy was found trapped under a metal shutter. A concrete slab was poised above him — held up by a flattened motorcycle.
lead_paragraph: KATMANDU, Nepal — Five days had passed since an earthquake devastated Nepal, and rescue teams had largely given up hope of finding anyone else alive among the piles of brick and broken concrete that litter Katmandu. Then on Thursday, in a part of the city dense with cheap hotels and shops, rescuers turned off a mechanical shovel and — in the relative silence — heard a cry.

headline: Billy Donovan Leaves Florida After 19 Years to Coach N.B.A.’s Thunder
abstract: Donovan, who led the University of Florida to two national titles in men’s basketball in 19 years, replaces Scott Brooks, who was fired last week.
lead_paragraph: Billy Donovan, who coached the University of Florida to two national championships and four Final Fours in 19 seasons, resigned on Thursday to become the head coach of the Oklahoma City Thunder, the N.B.A. team announced on Thursday.

headline: Did Psychologists Help the Government Torture?
abstract: A new report raises the disturbing possibility that the American Psychological Association aided the Bush administration in justifying illegal torture.
lead_paragraph: One of the more disturbing aspects of the Bush administration’s twisted justifications for torturing prisoners after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks was that the C.I.A.’s jailers were using medical personnel to monitor interrogations and essentially give their blessing to the abuse.

headline: Taxi Driver, 92, Crashes Into Long Island Home and Is Killed
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Joseph Saccente drove through several lawns and struck multiple mailboxes before crashing into the living room of a house in West Sayville, N.Y.
lead_paragraph: A 92-year-old taxi driver lost control of his vehicle on Thursday, driving through several lawns, striking multiple mailboxes and ultimately crashing into the living room of a home on Long Island, the police said.

headline: A Wallpaper Pop-Up Puts Surprising Patterns on Display
abstract: Soy Este sets up shop in Amé Amé with a Swatch Roller that cycles through a dozen different prints.
lead_paragraph: “I’m into dollar store and supermarket culture — I walk around and see things, and immediately see their potential,” says Este Lewis, the multidisciplinary artist and founder of the independent design company Soy Este. She has translated her fondness for the familiar into a range of wallpaper patterns, 12 of which will be featured by the Manhattan store Amé Amé for May and June on a hanging, motorized belt, dubbed the “Swatch Roller.” Among the selected arrangements: “Ruth Bender Fruit Roll-Up,” which overlaps prints of the yoga pioneer and scans of the snack; “Blueberry Stains on Paper Towel,” a kind of tie-dye motif; and “Cinnamon Gum,” a reference to the classic Twin Peaks line “That gum you like is going to come back in style.” For Lewis, the Swatch Roller is an extension of the very interactive Soy Este site — a way to sell her wares and “also, an art piece in and of itself, a studio space and a space for other people to imagine being in, but it’s real,” she says. “There’s so much imagination within the Internet … and the patterns are patterns, but the wallpaper is a method of archiving our everyday.”

headline: Grateful for, and Wary of, Extra Force
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Demonstrations, Protests and Riots']
abstract: Residents of Baltimore’s downtown areas largely view the influx of State Police and National Guard members positively. But blocks from where Freddie Gray was arrested, residents are much more wary.
lead_paragraph: Residents of Baltimore’s downtown areas largely view the influx of State Police and National Guard members positively. But blocks from where Freddie Gray was arrested, residents are much more wary.

abstract: If this van is a-rockin’, the ’70s are a-knockin’.
lead_paragraph: If this van is a-rockin’, the ’70s are a-knockin’.

lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders, Independent of Vermont, entered the 2016 race in challenge to Hillary Rodham Clinton, calling the current economic situation immoral, wrong and unsustainable.

headline: Freddie Gray’s Injury and the Police ‘Rough Ride’
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The police say that Mr. Gray was not in a seatbelt, making some wonder if he was hurt by being taken on a “rough ride,” a longtime means of retribution for the police.
lead_paragraph: In Baltimore, they call it a “rough ride.” In Philadelphia, they had another name for it that hints at the age of the practice — a “nickel ride,” a reference to old-time amusement park rides that cost five cents. Other cities called them joy rides.

headline: Bratton Explores Giving Warnings in Lieu of Arrests for Minor Offenses
abstract: The comments by William J. Bratton, the New York police commissioner, came amid a debate over the policing of minority communities and a conversation in the city about altering some practices.
lead_paragraph: For Police Commissioner William J. Bratton, keeping crime low in New York City hinges on the power of officers to make arrests for low-level offenses. Not that they must actually do so.

headline: Alex Rodriguez Is Back at Fenway. Let the Booing Begin.
abstract: Rodriguez, who made his career debut in Boston in 1994, will resume his tempestuous relationship with Red Sox fans this weekend, when the Yankees visit for three games.
lead_paragraph: Fenway Park was the stage on which Alex Rodriguez was first introduced to Major League Baseball. It was a cool, rainy evening in Boston on July 8, 1994, and the gathering specter of a players’ strike threatened to shut down the sport.

headline: Martin O’Malley Was Born to Run
abstract: The former Democratic governor of Maryland — and potential presidential candidate — on running against Hillary, the value of negative ads and playing guitar in an Irish rock band.
lead_paragraph: Update: Jim Rutenberg spoke with Martin O’Malley this week about the events in Baltimore, a week and a half after this interview was conducted. Read that conversation here.

headline: Martin O’Malley: ‘We Never Encouraged Aggressive Policing’
abstract: The former Baltimore mayor and Maryland governor addresses criticism of his legacy in the wake of Freddie Gray’s death.
lead_paragraph: When I interviewed Martin O’Malley, a former Democratic governor of Maryland, in Baltimore this month, part of our conversation centered on crime and policing in that city, where he served as mayor from 1999 to 2007. A great deal has happened in Baltimore since that interview, of course. Shortly after we spoke, the city’s mayor and police chief announced that the Police Department was suspending six officers after the death of Freddie Gray.

headline: On Baltimore, Hillary Clinton Is Half Right
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Discrimination', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Speeches and Statements', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The solutions she proposes are good ones, but she’s far from the first to suggest them.
lead_paragraph: Give Hillary Clinton credit for stepping up, in a speech at Columbia University on Wednesday, to the rioting in Baltimore and the confounding American problems of poverty and violence, racial injustice and criminal policing.

headline: Frozen Embryos Article Was Intended to Spark Debate: Mission Accomplished.
abstract: The editorial page editor responds to reader criticism of Nick Loeb’s Op-Ed essay.
lead_paragraph: An Op-Ed essay titled “Sofía Vergara’s Ex-Fiancé: Our Frozen Embryos Have a Right to Live” started to draw fire almost immediately after its publication Wednesday night.

headline: Hank Greenberg Still in the Ring at 90, Battling A.I.G. Charges
keywords: ['Frauds and Swindling', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: Mr. Greenberg, soon to turn 90, is scheduled to take the witness stand in July after years of discovery and maneuvers in the fraud case that accuses him of accounting fraud.
lead_paragraph: To his accusers, Maurice R. Greenberg, also known as Hank, is just one in a line of disgraced chief executives from the mid-2000s who resorted to accounting fraud to pad their lavish bonuses. But even they have to admit one thing: The man has stamina.

headline: Review: ‘Embracing Modernism: Ten Years of Drawings Acquisitions’ at the Morgan Runs a Gamut
abstract: This show of nearly 100 drawings is a partial report on the health of the Morgan itself.
lead_paragraph: No museum exhibition is perfect, but some are less perfect than others. Surprisingly, even these shows sometimes turn out to be exceptionally valuable. They clarify notions of quality and the pleasures and rigors of looking, for curators and visitors alike.

headline: Lil Buck at Versailles, as Apollo. Seriously.
abstract: Lil Buck, the jookin street dance phenomenon, will perform a solo at Versailles on May 10 and 11.
lead_paragraph: The Parisian artist Jean-Michel Othoniel’s gilded glass fountains won’t be the only things dancing at opening parties for the restored Water Theater grove in the gardens of the Château de Versailles in May. L.A. Dance Project will present the latest addition to its repertoire in the newly landscaped space on May 10 and 11, with a guest solo performance by the jookin street dance phenomenon Lil Buck, starring as the sun god Apollo.

headline: Review: ‘Discovering Japanese Art’ Presents Collections at the Met
abstract: This gorgeous exhibition includes more than 200 works spanning 16 centuries, grouped by the collections the museum acquired, including those of Frank Lloyd Wright and American tycoons.
lead_paragraph: Most Frank Lloyd Wright fans know that he was influenced by Japanese aesthetics. Fewer are aware that during the first quarter of the 20th century that American architect pursued a lucrative side career as a dealer in Japanese prints. When he was working on designs for the Imperial Hotel in Tokyo, Wright said that print vendors lined up outside his office door. This business helped save his architectural practice during its less solvent periods. Years later he recalled that sales of Japanese prints “practically built Taliesin I and II.”

headline: Murder Charge for Woman Who Said Fiancé’s Kayak Capsized in Hudson River
abstract: Angelika Graswald, 35, told the New York State Police that Vincent Viafore, 46, had slipped under the frigid surface when his kayak capsized during a weekend excursion.
lead_paragraph: MIDDLETOWN, N.Y. — For days, the New York State Police scoured the sandy shorelines of the Hudson River, looking for a man whose fiancée said had slipped under the frigid surface when his kayak capsized during a weekend excursion.

headline: The DJ and Nightlife Arbiter Venus X Shares Her Inspirations
abstract: GHE20G0TH1K, her long-running, now-cancelled underground party, will return for one night only this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The world may know Venus X as MIA’s tour DJ and backup vocalist, but X — née Jazmin Venus Soto — is so much more than MIA’s stage sidekick: she’s a connector, style evangelist and most importantly, the founder of the long-running underground party GHE20G0TH1K. “It’s not your typical night in New York,” X, 28, says of the party. “It’s artists, DJs and musicians who want to enjoy what the status quo enjoys, but they want to experiment with who is at the party and how people are dressing, as opposed to a club where you usually have a straight, gay, black, white or Hispanic crowd where people and music aren’t mixing.” By combining urban and punk aesthetics — the “ghetto gothic” idea — X’s party, founded in 2009, has had a hand in a cultural movement, especially in the style community. A longtime friend of Hood by Air’s Shayne Oliver, she has worked with the brand, making music for commercials, runway shows and after-parties, since 2010. She wore Hood by Air in A$AP Rocky’s first major music video, “Peso,” in 2011, and played an integral role in launching its women’s line in fall 2014, creating a live sound installation alongside Fatima Al Qadiri. She’s also worked with Patrik Ervell and Phillip Lim, among others.

abstract: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, Vietnam and the United States.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Nepal, Burundi, Vietnam and the United States.

headline: A Belated Retrospective for a Bauhaus Artist
abstract: An art dealer in Massachusetts is opening a show of works by Hannes Beckmann, a Bauhaus-trained painter who was also a photographer and stage designer.
lead_paragraph: Hannes Beckmann, a Bauhaus-trained painter who was also a photographer and stage designer, narrowly survived World War II. He fled his native Germany, ended up imprisoned in Czechoslovakia and lost much of his artwork along the way. After tracking down some of Mr. Beckmann’s surviving works in recent years, David Hall, an art dealer in Wellesley, Mass., is opening a retrospective on Monday.

headline: Change to a Segregated Monument Is Stymied by a Law Protecting It
abstract: Greenwood wants to replace memorial plaques that list war dead by race. But state law requires legislative approval, which the city does not have.
lead_paragraph: GREENWOOD, S.C. — The bronze plaques on Main Street silently tell the toll of the two world wars on this small county: 197 men, listed by name but uncategorized by rank or age or branch of service.

headline: Review: Audra McDonald at Carnegie Hall, Paying Tribute to Musical Theater
abstract: Ms. McDonald’s concert put the spotlight on relatively obscure songs from well-known Broadway shows.
lead_paragraph: “Songs From My Living Room” was the informal title of Audra McDonald’s forward-looking Carnegie Hall concert on Wednesday evening. That meant a mixture of recent theater songs and vintage show tunes, many associated with her musical role models — Chita Rivera, Betty Buckley, Barbara Cook, Judy Garland — when she was growing up in Fresno, Calif., dreaming of Broadway stardom.

headline: Mayor de Blasio Defends Police Response to Freddie Gray Protests in New York
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']
abstract: A day after 143 people in Manhattan were arrested during demonstrations, city officials said any escalation on the part of the police was provoked by protesters who sought to cause trouble.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Bill de Blasio, facing an uproar over arrests at a Manhattan rally to protest strong-armed policing, offered a spirited defense of law enforcement on Thursday, brushing off concerns that demonstrators had been mistreated even as he insisted on his own commitment to reform.

headline: Review: Kate Atkinson’s ‘A God in Ruins’ Offers Lives Skipping Among Eras
abstract: Ms. Atkinson’s latest novel uses circular chronologies to tell a multigenerational family story.
lead_paragraph: In a churlish note at the end of her subtly fine new novel, “A God in Ruins,” Kate Atkinson talks about an author’s right to remain uncertain about what she has accomplished until she has actually done it. It’s “as if there is a part of the writing brain that knows what it’s doing and another part that is woefully ignorant,” she says.

headline: Complaints in Baltimore About Law Offering Protections for Officers
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: Commonly known as the police officers’ bill of rights, among its provisions is giving officers 10 days before they have to talk to investigators.
lead_paragraph: As Justice Department officials began meeting with community leaders in Baltimore this week in the early stages of their civil rights inquiry into the death of Freddie Gray, they heard repeated complaints about a state law that gives special legal protections to police officers suspected of abusing their power.

abstract: The bronze heads in this elegant show seem to be predicting divine retribution.
lead_paragraph: With the haunting bronze heads in this elegant show, the Brooklyn sculptor Sarah Peters scores an aesthetic hat trick: making works that appear antique, Modern and post-Modern all at once.

abstract: For $1.3 million, a foreigner can obtain a Maltese passport, residency with tax advantages and freedom to move throughout the European Union.
lead_paragraph: VALLETTA, Malta — As wealthy foreigners rush to get citizenship in Malta under a new program, the residency requirement is taking many forms.

headline: Review: Allan deSouza, ‘Notes From Afar’
abstract: Mr. deSouza offers a photographic response to Jacob Lawrence’s “Migration Series.”
lead_paragraph: In 2011, the Phillips Collection in Washington commissioned Allan deSouza to create a photographic response to Jacob Lawrence’s 60-painting “Migration Series” (1940-41), half of which is owned by the Phillips, the other half by the Museum of Modern Art in New York (where the entire work is on display through Sept. 7). The Lawrence cycle tells the story of the great diaspora of African-Americans, beginning in World War I, from the rural South to the industrialized North. Mr. deSouza, who was born in Kenya of South Asian parentage and lives in California, has long made displacement and alienation a subject of his art and does so again in “The World Series,” his incisive update to the older work.

headline: Review: Lisa Yuskavage at David Zwirner
abstract: Ms. Yuskavage’s paintings need to push more envelopes.
lead_paragraph: Lisa Yuskavage’s paintings need to push more envelopes. Their societal salvos are well aimed, but formally and stylistically they should unsettle notions about painting in more profound, less completely parodic ways. With their protruding chests, slinky pelvises and scanty dress, Ms. Yuskavage’s creatures inhabit greasy surfaced, pastel worlds whose acid hues often hijack the modernist love of color for color’s sake. Rankling several standards of taste, she reclaims women’s pleasure as their own while sometimes evoking metaphorically the repressions such freedom can invite. “Triptych,” the largest painting in Ms. Yuskavage’s previous solo show at Zwirner (in 2011), suggested the blood sacrifice of one of her sprites by stern pioneer women from the Old West.

headline: Review: Pam Lins, ‘model model model’
abstract: Ms. Lins explores the connection between photography and sculpture.
lead_paragraph: Much has been made of the relationship between photography and painting; less so the one between photography and sculpture. Pam Lins’s current show includes two projects that explore that connection.

headline: Review: ‘Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980’ at MoMA
abstract: The exhibition recalls a not-so-distant time when architects and governments in the region dreamed big about changing the world for the better.
lead_paragraph: Some years ago I sat on the gusty, sun-drenched roof deck of a beachside hotel in Rio de Janeiro sipping ice tea with Maria Elisa Costa. A half-century earlier, her father, Lúcio Costa, had devised the master plan for Brasília, which is pretty much where a new, extraordinary exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, “Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980,” begins.

headline: Sarah Dahlgren, New York Fed’s Top Bank Supervisor, to Leave
abstract: No reason was given for the resignation of Sarah J. Dahlgren, who was promoted in recent years as part the Fed’s efforts to bolster its regulatory efforts.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which has recently faced strong criticism of its oversight of Wall Street, announced on Thursday that its head of bank supervision plans to leave at the end of year.

headline: Grandeur to Spare
abstract: Chris Impey, the author of “Beyond: Our Future in Space,” says: “I grew up in a small, damp, cloudy country. The stars and space were not prominent in my childhood.”
lead_paragraph: Lee Billings reviews Chris Impey’s “Beyond: Our Future in Space” this week. Impey, a professor at the University of Arizona, was born in Britain, and said in a recent email interview that he came to astronomy as a teenager.

headline: Review: ‘Your Blues Ain’t Sweet Like Mine’ Takes On Race
abstract: Ruben Santiago-Hudson’s drama, at Two River Theater in New Jersey, is less a play than a poignant, often powerful polemic.
lead_paragraph: RED BANK, N.J. — At a dinner party on the Upper West Side, Zeke (Brandon J. Dirden) reels off his own personal A B C’s: A is for the Arawak, victims of genocide. B is for bombings in Birmingham. C is for chains. D is for denied. E is for Emmett Till. The other guests stop him before he can get much further into the alphabet.

headline: A ‘Baby Instrument’ All Grown Up
abstract: For its 20th anniversary, and for fun, the Recorder Orchestra is offering a free concert.
lead_paragraph: Patsy Rogers has heard it all before.

headline: Review: ‘Revolution of the Eye’ Examines Art’s Influence on Early TV
abstract: The new exhibition at the Jewish Museum examines network television’s knowing if informal relationship with the high art of the time.
lead_paragraph: Walk into “Revolution of the Eye,” a revealing new exhibition that opens Friday at the Jewish Museum, and you’re face to face with the 23-year-old Barbra Streisand dashing about in a riotously colored Op-Art dress, singing, “Gotta find some place ... Some place where I can just be me.”

headline: Oliver Jeffers’s Art of Bearing Witness
abstract: For a performance project, the painter dipped completed portraits into vats of paint in front of an audience, obscuring them.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night in Brooklyn, in an elevator that was once used to move cars between floors of a belt factory, Oliver Jeffers destroyed months of work in front of a dozen witnesses, and then offered them a drink. The Northern Irish, Brooklyn-based artist (he’s exhibited at the National Portrait Gallery, but is perhaps best known for his children’s books and work with U2), had spent months creating a portrait of a middle-aged African American woman grasping a chicken in one hand and a viper in the other. Last night, he dipped it in a vat of green paint, a bright shade of sickly lime enamel, covering all but the top of her head. With that, an assistant passed around shots of whiskey and glasses were raised: “What’s done is done, and what’s to come is to come.”

lead_paragraph: UNIONDALE, N.Y. — The Islanders have just begun processing another heart-wrenching playoff loss, but this forced foray into summer feels different.

headline: Shira Piven on Directing ‘Welcome to Me,’ a Comedy of Disorder
abstract: Ms. Piven strove to balance a dark comedy with the humanity of its protagonist: “We find her hilarious, but we also find her sad and touching.”
lead_paragraph: In the new film “Welcome to Me,” Kristen Wiig plays Alice Klieg, an unemployed, mentally ill veterinary technician who goes off her meds, wins the lottery and buys her way into hosting a talk show. Then the fun — in the form of borderline personality disorder, reckless spending and puppy surgery — really starts. “It has hilarious moments and dark moments, and I really like living in that world,” the director, Shira Piven, said.

headline: Review: At Paloma in Stamford, a Combination of Latin Foods
abstract: Chef Aarón Sánchez has figured out a way to bring together the best of Spanish, South and Central American cuisines.
lead_paragraph: In this era of wall-to-wall television shows about chefs competing, fighting and sometimes even cooking, some diners like to go to restaurants with a camera-ready face at the helm.

headline: Qatar Joins List of Countries Buying Fighter Jets From France
abstract: President François Hollande said the deal called for sale of 24 Rafale jets, following contracts with India and Egypt.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France announced on Thursday a multibillion dollar sale of military aircraft to Qatar, the country’s third such deal with a foreign government this year.

headline: Squid Sticks After Dark at the Queens International Night Market
abstract: Visitors swarmed the 20 food tents of the Queens International Night Market on the first of 16 scheduled evenings of its first year.
lead_paragraph: Last weekend, well before the Queens International Night Market had officially opened, long lines had already started to form. Visitors swarmed the 20 food tents set up in a corner of the roughly 100,000-square-foot parking lot outside the New York Hall of Science, at Flushing Meadows-Corona Park.

headline: Easing Diabetes Risk, One Beverage at a Time
abstract: Substituting just one serving a day of water or unsweetened tea or coffee for one serving of a sugar-sweetened soft drink or dairy beverage can significantly reduce the incidence of Type 2 diabetes, a new study has found.

headline: Review: Kristen Wiig as a Troubled Lottery Winner in ‘Welcome to Me’
abstract: Ms. Wiig’s character decides to spend a major financial windfall on buying her own talk show in this dark comedy directed by Shira Piven.
lead_paragraph: “Welcome to Me” is the name of a television show created by Alice Klieg, a California woman — divorced, unemployed, coping with borderline personality disorder, off her medication — who financed it with money she won in the state lottery. Alice is the program’s guiding creative spirit and also its star, so the content reflects her interests: low-“carbohydrant” cooking, swan figurines, the neutering of dogs, re-enacted episodes of childhood humiliation and, above all, herself. She is both unstable and self-absorbed, and though she has spent years studying the broadcast work of Oprah Winfrey on VHS, Alice’s on-air gestures and intonations can be as awkward as her self-help pronouncements are bizarre. From the start, “Welcome to Me,” shot in front of a sparse audience in the studios of a struggling infomercial outfit, seems to be headed for disaster.

headline: New Whitney Museum Signifies a Changing New York Art Scene
abstract: The Whitney accommodates art and people with equal finesse, emerging bigger and better from the process of building a new home.
lead_paragraph: For the last week, thousands of New York art followers have been paying their first visits to the Whitney Museum of American Art’s hospitable new home and its history-stretching inaugural exhibition, the largest ever of works from its permanent collection.

headline: Homeland Security Official Defends Handling of Visa Program
abstract: Alejandro Mayorkas conceded that his actions created an impression of political favoritism, but said he interfered to “to make sure we were adhering to the law.”
lead_paragraph: The deputy secretary of Homeland Security, Alejandro Mayorkas, conceded at a congressional hearing on Thursday that his intervention in three cases of visas for foreign investors had created an impression of political favoritism, and he said he regretted fostering that perception. But he defended the results of his involvement, saying he had helped “to make sure we were adhering to the law.”

headline: Woman in Punjab Is Killed After Being Molested on Bus
keywords: ['Murders, Attempted Murders and Homicides', 'Buses', 'Sex Crimes', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Four men were arrested on Thursday in connection with the case, in which the young woman, who was traveling with her mother, sustained a head injury, according to the police.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — A young woman traveling in Punjab on Wednesday evening was killed after she and her mother were molested and thrown from a private bus by a group of men, the mother said.

headline: Jury in Etan Patz Trial Rehears Defense Summation on Day 12 of Deliberating
abstract: The Manhattan jurors deciding the fate of a man accused of killing Etan in 1979 revisited the defense summation before resuming their deliberations, a day after the panel announced it was deadlocked.
lead_paragraph: A day after announcing it was deadlocked, the jury in the Etan Patz murder case listened to a reading of the entire defense summation again on Thursday, absorbing three and a half hours of argument and watching several video clips before resuming its deliberations.

headline: ‘Far From the Madding Crowd’ (With Movie Trailer): Thomas Vinterberg Narrates a Scene
abstract: The director Thomas Vinterberg discusses a sequence from “Far From the Madding Crowd,” his film adaptation of the Thomas Hardy novel with Carey Mulligan and Tom Sturridge.
lead_paragraph: Thomas Hardy’s 1874 novel “Far From the Madding Crowd” has been adapted several times for film and television over the years. But the Danish director Thomas Vinterberg sought to bring something fresh to the story of Bathsheba Everdene (Carey Mulligan), a farm owner who is courted by three men. In this video, she secretly meets one of her suitors, Francis Troy (Tom Sturridge), in the forest. In a recent interview, Mr. Vinterberg, who usually writes the films he directs, spoke about working on this adaptation.

headline: Review: ‘Far From the Madding Crowd,’ the Rom-Com
abstract: Carey Mulligan stars in Thomas Vinterberg’s adaptation of the Thomas Hardy novel, with Matthias Schoenaerts, Tom Sturridge and Michael Sheen as her Victorian suitors.
lead_paragraph: Bathsheba Everdene — if the last name sounds familiar, that’s because she’s an acknowledged feminist foremother of the “Hunger Games” heroine — is faced with a series of complicated choices. Really, though, her predicament is simple: She wants to live on her own terms in a society where a woman’s freedom is tightly circumscribed by custom and expectation. As she tries to figure out what she wants to do and who she wants to be, the world keeps pushing her to answer a different question: Which man will she marry?

headline: 145 Writers Sign Letter Protesting PEN Award to Charlie Hebdo
abstract: Among those who have signed the letters: Junot Díaz, Lorrie Moore, Joyce Carol Oates, Eric Bogosian and Michael Cunningham.
lead_paragraph: Junot Díaz, Lorrie Moore, Joyce Carol Oates, Eric Bogosian and Michael Cunningham are among the 145 writers  listed as signatories on  a letter protesting PEN American Center’s decision to award its “freedom of expression courage” award to the French satirical weekly Charlie Hebdo, because the award seems to endorse drawings of the prophet Muhammad and other images that “must be seen as being intended to cause further humiliation and suffering” among France’s embattled Muslims.

headline: Baby Boom Among New York’s Affluent
abstract: The city’s birthrate is steadily declining, but not among the affluent, and that rise is changing the feel of the city.
lead_paragraph: Over the past decade or so as $10 million apartments have prevailed in New York and more and more neighborhoods have been given over to the kind of luxury shopping required to fill them, it has been common to say that the city has turned into a “playground for the rich.” At the same time, of course, New York has turned into a playground of the more literal kind, with a child-centric ethos bearing well-established variants of urban nuisance: stroller gridlock in gentrifying areas, car services that cater to 5-year-olds, sidewalk whining that in some cases becomes its own source of noise pollution. (When you can hear Amadeus demanding a second packet of Pirate’s Booty from your fourth-floor walk-up on West 83rd Street, do you feel like calling 311?)

headline: Lost in Nepal’s Quake, but Preserved in Photos
abstract: With thousands dead and entire communities destroyed, the Nepal Picture Library’s archives may be the only surviving record of what was lost in the recent earthquake.
lead_paragraph: With thousands dead and entire communities destroyed, the Nepal Picture Library’s archives may be the only surviving record of what was lost in the recent earthquake.

lead_paragraph: Think of the Instagram hashtag ArquiMoMA as an epilogue to the Museum of Modern Art’s “Latin America in Construction: Architecture 1955-1980.”

headline: Review: Gurrumul, an Aboriginal Singer, Makes U.S. Debut
abstract: Gurrumul, an aboriginal singer-songwriter, sang about tradition and relationships in a concert at SubCulture in the East Village.
lead_paragraph: There’s something preternaturally soothing about the voice of Gurrumul, an Australian aboriginal singer and songwriter who made his United States debut on Wednesday night at SubCulture. It seems to arrive from a distance, high and serene, with a hint of reediness and a humble quaver, proffering melodies like lullabies.

headline: Time Away Doesn’t Mean Time Off
abstract: Plus: answers to questions about offering fashion advice, lending a car and a sister’s dating advice.
lead_paragraph: How should I handle colleagues who refer to my impending six-to-eight-week maternity leave as vacation? So far, I’ve received comments such as, “Wow, I wish I could have a two-month vacation!” and “I hope you enjoy your break.” I have tried referring to this period as “medical disability leave,” but that hasn’t changed the general perception that I will be loafing around. Any ideas?

headline: ‘Days of Grace,’ a Mexican Film by Everardo Gout
abstract: The film uses three plotlines that take place during successive World Cups, in 2002, 2006 and 2010.
lead_paragraph: “Days of Grace,” the debut feature from Everardo Gout, a Mexican filmmaker with a background in music videos and television commercials, weaves together three stories of violence and corruption in Mexico City. Braided narratives are a way for directors both to show off their chops and to illuminate social issues and complex themes. Mr. Gout combines a slick, kinetic style with a somber ethical sense. His movie is flashy and entertaining, but also earnestly concerned with the collapse of trust and integrity at every level of society.

lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Avengers: Age of Ultron,” “Iris” and “Welcome to Me.”

headline: Community Leaders Share Ideas on How to Quell Urban Violence
keywords: ['Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Urban Areas', 'Police', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Vocational Training']
abstract: Local officials attended a convention held by Cities United, a national organization dedicated to ending violence among African-American men and boys.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — More than 300 community leaders at a convention about 100 miles from the turmoil in Baltimore are pondering issues of policing, urban poverty and the effects of law enforcement on urban life.

headline: N.F.L. and Networks Ensure Scoops Don’t Ruin Suspense
abstract: The league has used its clout to secure agreements with networks that reporters would not report who was being drafted in advance.
lead_paragraph: The N.F.L. draft should feel like Christmas for Adam Schefter of ESPN, who has established himself as the pro football reporter whose immense social media following is a testament to his ability to break news. Schefter, one could assume, might be relishing the chance to reveal what is going on in the draft before a league official announces it.

headline: Review: In ‘Far From Men,’ a Teacher Caught in the Crossfire
abstract: Two starkly different men are thrown together in this film inspired by a short story by Albert Camus.
lead_paragraph: In “Far From Men,” Viggo Mortensen, his sharply planed face weathered and solemn, plays a man who looks as if he were quarried right out of the hard red-rock earth. He plays Daru, a teacher who imparts the names of French rivers to eager Algerian children in a small white schoolhouse that’s nestled in a valley and ringed by jagged desert mountains. There’s something haunted about this wildly beautiful place with its thirsty ground and sparse vegetation, though only partly because the story takes place in 1954, the year the fight for Algerian independence ignited.

headline: Review: In ‘Hyena,’ a Rogue Cop Finds Himself in Too Deep
abstract: As kingpins do battle in London in Gerald Johnson’s drama, there’s plenty of human trafficking, drug smuggling and viscera.
lead_paragraph: “Hyena,” Gerard Johnson’s corrupt-cop drama, is the kind of gory British policier from which you come away with the queasy feeling that the world is essentially a butcher shop ruled by greed, murder, cruelty and lust. American equivalents like “Bad Lieutenant” at least have a moral compass, however twisted. British crime films in a similar mode (I’m thinking particularly of “Filth”) begin from the Hobbesian presumption that, as Mick Jagger sings in “Sympathy for the Devil,” “every cop is a criminal.”

headline: Gay Marriage Backers to Finance Anti-Discrimination Efforts

abstract: With gay marriage being debated by the United States Supreme Court, some of the major backers of efforts to legalize it around the country are casting their attention to the next fight: anti-discrimination bills in a variety of states.
lead_paragraph: With gay marriage being debated by the United States Supreme Court, some of the major backers of efforts to legalize it around the country are casting their attention to the next fight: anti-discrimination bills in a variety of states.

headline: Review: ‘Cas & Dylan,’ a Road Movie Starring Richard Dreyfuss
abstract: The film follows a pair of mismatched travelers heading across Canada.
lead_paragraph: Why another road movie about bickering mismatched travelers warily making friends on a cross-country journey? That cliché weighs heavily on “Cas & Dylan,” the feature film directorial debut of Jason Priestley (known mostly from his acting role on “Beverly Hills 90210”), even after you queasily succumb to the sentimentality of this formulaic two-hander.

headline: A Worse-Than-Expected $55 Million First-Quarter Loss for DreamWorks Animation
abstract: Jeffrey Katzenberg, DreamWorks Animation’s chief executive, says this is ‘a transitional year’ for the studio.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — After a brutal six months marked by creative retrenchments and two failed merger attempts, DreamWorks Animation on Thursday reported a first-quarter loss of $54.8 million.

headline: Review: In ‘Ride,’ Helen Hunt Goes Surfing
abstract: Directed and written by Ms. Hunt, this movie follows a high-strung New Yorker editor as she tracks down her son on the West Coast.
lead_paragraph: A more accurate title for “Ride,” a wobbly underdeveloped comedy starring Helen Hunt, who directed and wrote the screenplay, would be “How I Learned to Surf.” As an instructional movie on the sport, “Ride” offers some useful tips, but beyond that, it feels like a slightly bizarre vanity project.

headline: Judge Reduces 3 Sentences in Atlanta School Testing Scandal
abstract: Saying he was “not comfortable” with the original seven-year prison terms he imposed, Judge Jerry W. Baxter cut them to three years.
lead_paragraph: ATLANTA — Admitting that he was “not comfortable” with the seven-year prison terms he had handed down two weeks earlier, the judge in the Atlanta Public Schools cheating case on Thursday called three former administrators back to his courtroom to cut their prison terms to three years each.

headline: Review: In ‘Cathedrals of Culture,’ Buildings to Love
abstract: A two-part program of short films by directors including Wim Wenders and Robert Redford tours structures that transcend mere architectural concerns.
lead_paragraph: As houses of God, Europe’s cathedrals were built to be something more than mere stone, something that could transport and transform. In the omnibus film “Cathedrals of Culture,” subtitled “A 3D Film Project About the Soul of Buildings,” the secular structures on display are scarcely less ambitious, and the strongest of the film’s six chapters reflect filmmakers searching to express higher states of being.

headline: Plan Unveiled to Overhaul School System in Detroit
abstract: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan calls for one entity to manage debt and another to oversee day-to-day school operations.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Rick Snyder of Michigan unveiled a proposal on Thursday to overhaul the failing Detroit public school system by creating two districts — one to manage paying off billions of dollars in debt, the other to oversee the day-to-day operations of the schools.

headline: Review: In ‘Gerontophilia,’ a Youth Is Attracted to Old Men
abstract: This Bruce LaBruce film is a sincere and tastefully observed indie romance, flavored with a sweetly droll sense of humor.
lead_paragraph: Coming from the director of “No Skin Off My Ass” and “The Raspberry Reich,” “Gerontophilia” might sound like just another gleefully raunchy provocation: An 18-year-old man is uncontrollably attracted to old men, despite being involved with a spirited, radical-minded young woman. But the mild style that the filmmaker Bruce LaBruce slips on for his new feature is that of tastefully observed indie romance, flavored with a sweetly droll sense of humor but never to the point of undermining the sincerity of its intentions.

headline: Nepal’s Earthquake Recovery Begins, Even as Aftershocks Linger
abstract: A few rescues were among the rare bits of good news on an otherwise dreary and rainy day during which the enormity of the tragedy that has befallen Nepal continued to sink in.
lead_paragraph: A few rescues were among the rare bits of good news on an otherwise dreary and rainy day during which the enormity of the tragedy that has befallen Nepal continued to sink in.

headline: Kentucky Derby 2015: Predictions and Analysis
abstract: Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times weigh in on the contenders for the 141st Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: The horses for the 141st running of the Kentucky Derby are listed in order of post position, with comments by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. The morning-line odds were set by Mike Battaglia of Churchill Downs. (Note: International Star, who was to start from the No. 12 post, was scratched Saturday morning with a hoof issue. Frammento, an alternate entry who will wear saddle No. 21, was added to the field after the scratch of Stanford, who was to start from the No. 11 post. The horses will keep their program numbers but the first hole in the gate will be left open and each will move down a gate. For example, No. 1 Ocho Ocho Ocho will break from the second post but still be considered as breaking from Post 1.)
